reviewText:
I have mixed feelings on this game.   Ill start by saying that I own all the previous AOW games and have played them through many times.

I dont like some of the differences but the game is still cool, and the devs are still working on it.

The sound tracks from the older versions were better, IMO.   Plus the lack of a customizable playlist that existed in all other AOW games bothered me.

The change from 8 to 6 units per army...  I cant say I liked that.
Flying or floating units are no diffrent than any other now.   I understand why they changed it, but they didnt have to.
There is a huge gap in the power of the different teirs in 3.  Any lesser units are basically useless later.  In AOW1-2 even a tier 1 unit still had a chance to survive vs a tier 4.  Now? no way.  The power gap is too much.
The heroes in 3 are somewhat weaker.  Your armor and resists have a negligible effect.
The facing change that happens every time a unit is hit is really dumb.  Your heroes can be attacked from the rear several times because of it, it really makes your heroes feel useless when it happens and enemies always seem to focus on your heroes too.

Seems that some broader game mechanics were reduced in favor of prettier graphics.  Such as the army size.
Castle and tower walls are just graphics now.  They are pretty useless for slowing down the attackers and several times I felt that playing defence behind a wall was actually detrimental and did little to stop attacking forces.  In this regard I feel like a good defensivive strategy is a moot point.  In 1 and 2, seiging a walled city or tower was pretty difficult, as it should be.  AoW3 just has too may ways for units to circumvent or destroy the walls too easily.  I resorted to using the auto battle instead of torturing myself.

Magic domains in aow 3 are also another moot point.  Your leader should not be able to use any magic outside it like it was in 1-2.  I feel like this magic domain mechanic is anti AOW, which has allways been about wizards and their domains and their armies being powerless outside of them unless the leader was physically present.

If you never played an AOW game before, then these flaws probably wont be noticable and I recommend it to you.

But if your like me, the differences and dumbed down mechanics from aow1-2 will make you not like this game as much as the originals and possibly even regret buyng it.  Ive tried playing through the campaigns twice now, and the story is interesting, but the gameplay turns me off and I get tired of it.

reviewText:
A wonderful game!

This is what Heroes of Might and Magic 5,6 and 7 should have been like! Clearly developed to beat these titles and it succeeds I think!
Essentially Age of Wonders III is HOM&M but with far superior combat, tactics, spells, heroes and troop development.
The graphics are as good as later HOM&M titles but the 3D used here seems to work so much better than HOM&M I feel, the interface is also more intuitive. Though I loved Heroes of Might and Magic 1 to 4 I could never get used to the later version's interface but AOWIII improves on them greatly in almost all aspects. The one small issue with it is that the maps, at least in the Scenario's, do not seem quite as heavy on resources and independant enemies as HOM&M games but I guess this is because the game is trying to break away slightly here.
I will also say, it's HARD! I like this but was continually getting my backside kicked until I realise how much effect terrain variations had on different troops types! I love this and it really distinguishes it from HOM&M games where morale was a simple mechanism. AOWIII brilliantly bridges the gap between HOM&M and a more traditional squad/unit-based wargame.
Think of a cross between HOM&M and Warhammer and you are just about there :)

reviewText:
At the writing of this review I have just finished one random map on normal difficulty. I had a lot of fun with this game but there are a few things you should know before buying it.

This game excel with its tactical combats and it does it very well.  And the game is developed as a war game and the developers made this game around this concept, and you should accept this game as it is, a war game, where you need to carefully maneuver your units on a battle field behind covers, flanking enemies, exploiting enemy's weakness (elemental, armour, speed etc), and the game does it really well, and the ai is also very well done which employ a variety of tactics and is challenging even on normal.

Now about what this game isn't. It is not a sophisticated empire builder like Civilization. In fact, because the game is so build around the tactical combats, the designers want you to intelligently maneuver your troops tactically, that you simply cannot win by strategic planning alone. There are no super units that you can simply steam roll through your foes. There are no super spells that will wipe out an entire stack of enemy on the tactical map. It is even hard to win by economy alone because even with one city you can produce a quite powerful army, on standard map the resources are so aboundant that you simply cannot starve a city out.

Some people criticize the game because it is not what they expected, a fantasy Civilization game, and you should accept this game as it is, a very well done tactical war game.

I really love the presentation of this game, both the visual arts and music are full of imagination and epic. I did encounter a few freezes although they are relatively rare. I hope you enjoy this game as much as I do.

The one small issue with it is that the maps, at least in the Scenario's, do not seem quite as heavy on resources and independant enemies as HOM&M games but I guess this is because the game is trying to break away slightly here.
I will also say, it's HARD! I like this but was continually getting my backside kicked until I realise how much effect terrain variations had on different troops types! I love this and it really distinguishes it from HOM&M games where morale was a simple mechanism. AOWIII brilliantly bridges the gap between HOM&M and a more traditional squad/unit-based wargame.
Think of a cross between HOM&M and Warhammer and you are just about there :)

reviewText:
Age of Wonders 3 is a 4X turn based strategy game, with a fantasy setting. I haven't played the previous games in the series, and I'm not the most knowledgeable gamer when it comes to this genre as a whole. I've played a couple of games each in the Civilization and Total War franchises but not much else. In my non-expert view, AoW3 is a pretty good game, and I've had some fun with it.

Most concepts will be familiar to anyone who ever played a similar game. Expand your empire by creating cities, construct buildings to improve things like economy and production, research new technologies, train armies, move them around the world map and then take direct control on the battlefield.

AoW3 has a strong emphasis on combat, in fact every victory condition (at least in the campaign mode) is related to conquering your enemies, Total War style. There's no equivalent of Civ's peaceful victory conditions, however if you can create a diplomatic alliance with another faction, you are allowed to win together.

This isn't necessarily a complaint, because I like AoW3's battle system. The world map is divided into a hex grid, and each army stack can hold up to 6 units. When you attack, all the units in that hex and the 6 surrounding hexes, will be included in the battle. So the positioning of your armies becomes vital, and with a little tactical planning you can create a numerical advantage before the battle even begins.

The battlefield is where the game really comes to life for me, because of the fantasy theme. I love RPGs, so I really enjoyed the use of magic spells and supernatural creatures. There's an amazing variety of units in this game. Of course you've got the standard melee, cavalry and archer units, which function pretty much the same whether they are Human, Elf or Dwarf. But then you can have dragons that fly over castle walls, giants that just bash those walls down, unicorns can teleport behind an enemy, succubus can seduce an enemy to fight for you ... and so much more.

Your generals can cast spells to damage or stun the enemy, buff or heal your troops. They can equip loot, better weapons, armour and rings for passive buffs or resistance to elemental damage. They can gain XP and level up where once again, there are dozens of abilities to choose from.

The enemy AI is easily the best I've seen in this genre. Playing on normal difficulty, I was frequently punished for my mistakes. If I leave a city undefended, the enemy will capture it. I actually learned the importance of flanking the enemy for bonus damage, by watching the AI constantly doing it to me.

This is also the first strategy game that I've played that has a scripted story. Elves and Humans are at war, you can play as either side, and each chapter takes place on a different map. The story branches half way through based on a decision made by the player, and leads to one of three different endings. Dialogue is a mixture of voiced and text. And I must mention that the music is fantastic.

It took me 52 hours to complete one side of the campaign. Some of that is because I screwed up the later missions so badly that I had to restart the map and try a different tactic, but still, its long enough to make a full price purchase easily worth it. During all that time I don't recall noticing any bugs (unless you count Goblin Beetle riders ;)).

reviewText:
TL;DR: If you like a fantasy-themed, combat focused, round based X4 go get it. It's a very good game. The Golden Realms and Eternal Lords DLC are highly recommended as well.

When I say this a combat focused X4 I mean it - this game is probably focused mostly on the eXpand and eXterminate aspects of the X4 genre. Don't expect any deep dipomacy or city building aspect, it mainly focuses on expanding your empire and overthrowing your enemy. While the addons add additional victory conditions, still the focus is mainly on combat, however it does this very well with an insane amount of depth.

Battles are extremly strategic. Positioning and composition of your units matter a lot. Units can be flanked for extra damage, many units retaliate (fight back in melee) if they are attacked, or they do attacks of oppurnity on enemies that run past them. Ranged attacks deal damage depending on range and line of sight. Many units have active abilities often also reflecting the choice in your class (like dreadnaught class, for example engineers class units can reload other class units like cannons or muskeets that could otherwise only fire every two tactical rounds, all units only available to that class).

The whole element setup and unit-ability plays a huge role as well. If you defend your city with all archers (which deal physical damage) vs units that have high protection against physical damage, you'll have a hard time if you win at all. Casting spells here might save the day, since they could give your units elemental damage or lower the enemy resistance.

Obviously you want to mix up your units so that you a good chance of winning over attackers. When attacking a walled city, you probably want some way to finish off the defeners on the wall, either with spells or possibly with flying units or with units that can climb the walls. Or you choose to simply destroy the walls and then move in. Instead you use units who don't get a penality when shooting up the walls and simply shoot the defenders down. .

Cons:
* AI, while probably the best I've faced in a RBS 4X so far, suffers from the same problem that it can get rather predictable after a while
* End-game can be boring (usually turns into a steamroll/spam fest)
* Diplomacy is very basic
* Town management, while substantially improved with Golden Realms expansion, is rather basic

Pros:
* runs very smooth (on my system)
* visually fitting for the theme and overall very appealing
* story and lore is integrated into the game and the classes/units feel very thematic
* good music
* game includes character customization for your heros
* single player campaign while short is pretty good
* random maps have a decent amount of settings to customize
* AI is compared to other games very capable and can pose a threat (though of course, for a seasoned player you'll figure AI exploits eventually)
* modding toolkit/support
* classes play very differently and have their own flavour
* races also play somewhat differently and come with their own flavour (and strengths/weaknesses)
* specalizations allow you to further customize your playstyle
* spell casting

Fantastic:
* the class/race/specalization combinations make things highly varied (in particular to games like civ)
* RPG deeply integrated - units can level up, the game contains hero which are fully levelable complete with skills and equipment (which can also be found in encounters on the map as well as crafted in cities)
* tactical combat - this makes it possible to have very deep and tactical battles that can take a while. Unit placement, unit abilities, spell, everything matters

reviewText: A fantastic sequel that improves upon an already classic game. Anyone who enjoyed the original Age of Wonders installments would be doing themselves a disservice by ignoring this game. Improved combat (balancing, animation, visuals), Improved heroes (fewer objectively correct leveling choices, more interesting abilities), Improved main character (you are actually encouraged to use him as an aggressive unit now), Improved low level units (basic ranged units are actually worth while now, flanking allows low level melee units to maintain some relevance later in the game) and fantastic overland map rich with detail and a fantastic cloth world map ala Elemental/Fallen Enchantress. reviewText:
Domination is the name of the game, and luckily this game does that very well. If you are looking for complex building or research options, vast diplomacy networks and interactions.. then this is not the game for you. But if you are looking for fantastic, highly tactical turn-based combat in a good fantasy setting then Age of Wonders 3 is going to satisfy your needs. The strategic map has great detail and a real sense of atmosphere (the music certainly helps out a lot in this endeavor), and there are plenty of combat maps that have a beautiful layout. Unfortunately, siege maps lack variation (you will be fighting on these the most) but beyond that this game does conquest incredibly well.

Classes feel distinct and allow you to focus on your own playstyle, maps offer a lot of freedom and with two decent campaigns, scenarios and a good random map generator there is plenty for you to try out.

reviewText:
Age of Wonders III is an charming game but has too much cut and/or unfinished content to recommend, especially to fans of the older titles in this series, both which were filled to the brim with atmosphere.

THE GOOD:

- Music
Invigorating tunes that spur you on while you play, great remixes of old tracks while adding in a few new ones as well. Most are of great quality but due to the length of some instances (late-game world map micro-managing or lengthy battle sequences with large armies), the themes can seem to reoccur too often too quickly.

- Gameplay (Leader vurnability)
While defeat could come easily in Age of Wonder 1 when your leader died to a stray spell, Age of Wonders II made them too persistant with next turn revives and respawning at any city with a Wizard's Tower. Age of wonders 3 perfects this balance by granting the leader some form of revival but at a decent cost. All in all: Leaders are neither vurnable nor near-unkillable like they were in previous games, striking the perfect balance where all tactics can be considered during play to eliminate your opponent.

THE BAD:

- Graphics
While city-scapes during sieges can look amazing and army units are decent enough, there are equal as unpolished or plain bad textures as well. The leaders & heroes are the main offenders here: hair, beards and sometimes armor clipping or looking translucent, clothes or armor clipping through mounts,... Customizing your own leader has been expanded upon graphically, which I can only commend but the sore lack of extensive options makes this but a tiny timewaster rather than anything worthwhile. I confess, this is far more important in an RPG than it is in a TBS, but it looks half- nonetheless (example: No skin-tone for Dark Elves whilst the High Elves race is a mixture of both Wood Elves & Dark Elves). Furthermore, while some ingame items equipped to these heroes show up on their avatar and thus offers a nice nod to detail, other items do nothing of the sort. In my opinion, either do all or none of the items lest you create the notion you hadn't the time to bother with them all.

Some flying units have issues as well when fighting over lava or water. If the unit in question has an idle stance where it lands itself until ordered, it gets submerged nearly completely in said lava or water. Creating another idle animation when fighting over water or lava could have provided a solution here, as of now it just gnaws at the player's experience.


- Content
Age of Wonders 1 had 12 playable races, Age of Wonders 2 had 15 playable races (12 in the original, 3 extra in the expansion), Age of Wonders 3 has 6 of these races. Not only a major plunge in what you can play, but all units feel much the same with different skins. Although each races varies slightly from the standard template (Dwarves have 1 extra defense & resistance but cost 10% more gold to recruit, Orcs suffers -1 ranged damage yet gain +1 melee damage, etc...), none feel as diverse as they were in previous games. While some units do have unique abilities (Elf Unicorn Riders pack the Phase-ability, unique to them), their stats are nearly equal apart from their racial modifier! To me, the varied stats seemed to have a far greater impact in previous installments, contributing to each race's unique style. The only units I currently feel that make a unique impact over its peers are the Orc Greatsword and the Elf Gryphon Rider due to enhanced stats or extra abilities.

Next comes the story, spoiler tag inserted:

Even though they try to take the story into a new direction, this game only contains 6 or 7 missions per campaign to explain it. Aside from being utterly uninspired with an ending that just oozes: BUY OUR EXPANSION SINCE THIS RESOLVES NOTHING; all of these missions fall into the same tedious category of: Build a base from scratch against overwhelming enemy numbers who rarely do anything and sit there until you grind them piece by piece into a pulp." The last and fifth mission of the Elven campaign are notorious for this in my book. Aside from a few skirmishes into your terrain
date: they'll just wait until you come to besiege them. A few secrets here and there spruce up the lot

reviewText:
This game is great. I really like that the developers chose the right path, they not only did not move towards contraction but instead they actually introduced lots of new features into the game, which was very risky in the first place, knowing how conservative are fans in such games like AOW, Disciples and HMM. But in reality, compared to Heroes of Might and Magic and especially Disciples, which both went the wrong direction, this game is a masterpiece.

The new added features make the game different on the one hand, but also more interesting. I do not want to compare this game to Age of Wonders II, which of course is a living classics, but I can tell that this game has set the bar very high. This is obvious when you look at everything - the picture is amazing, it creates an impression of a beautiful fantasy world - very often I stopped the game in order to look at the map, take a look at the river, mountains, forests, and to look at how my pocket kingdom is doing. The music is great, altough I always consider the Age of Wonders II contained the best soundtrack of all times in games, the compositions of Michiel van den Bos are very powerful, and are used when they are actually needed, very often giving an additional inspiration in difficult battles.

I think the best argument which summarizes overall impression of the game is that there is always a wish to let the game go even when the map is already won. This is paradoxical on the one hand, because each map takes very long time to beat, but it was always a part of Age of Wonders gameplay, and compared to the previous games, in my opinion, it feels way faster. There are always so many things to do, do some research, build more buildings, recruit more units, build improvements, and to build new cities... So sometimes I regret that there is no single unified map like it is in Civilization, where you could develop a huge Empire and allow it to stand the test of time - this is perhaps the only bad thing about this game.


8.5 / 10

reviewText:
This game is exactly what I've been looking for: a decent fantasy strategy game.

I do have some slight issues:
1. Needs more Navy. I love naval combat. It's adds a different layer into the strategy game and makes it more interesting and challenging. Unfortunately there are only two fleet options in AoW: the frigate and the galleon.
2. I've found the Tigrans to be slightly OP. I started a game with Cerren and have tier I & II units just walking effortlessly over tier IV and higher units. Are they OP or an I just better with the Tigrans than I am with other races?
3. Sorcerers feel slightly OP. Sorcerers. Holy ! ing sorcerers! They start of weak then suddenly BAM! Unstoppable. But I can't judge AoW for that. They've always been like that.
3. Why don't assassins have throwing knives? Assassins without throwing knives or shuriken is like waffles without maple syrup.

What I love:
1. The tactics. Having to take into consideration race, class, morale, climate, terrain, and all these factors makes this game pretty damn sweet. I know it's not really a new concept, but it's a good one.
2. The world is beautiful.
3. The characters are beautiful.
4. I can customise my own heroes.
5. It saves after every turn, which is great if something goes wrong, like a blackout or a crash.

All in all I like this game a lot.

reviewText:
I really like this game and I think it's underrated. It consists of two parts; strategic world map and turn-based battles. I'll briefly explain each one here. There's a campaign mode which is fun but my favourite part of the game is the random map which you can customize the hell out of. There's an incredible amount of options for you to customize your own skirmish game. You can have a very short one with a small map, with huge amounts of resources and starting with large armies, or you can have a large map with lots of civilizations, slow research times, few starting resources (and few resources on the map) and so forth. You can even customize the terrain if you want to take the time, so there are a lot of options to suit your fancy.

You'll choose a race (human, orc, goblin, elf, etc.) and a class (warlord, theocrat, dradnought, sorcerer, etc) for your civilization. Each race has specific strengths and weaknesses and each class is very very different. A warlord civilization for example are focused on strong conventional armies, a dreadnought civilizationis focused on industry and powerful siege engines, a sorcerer civilization is magic based and so on. Your starting hero (which is like a leader of your overall civ and can be used as a general in your armies) will determine the class of your civilization, so choosing a warlord hero will make your civilization a warlord civ, but you can recruit other heroes of other classes as the game progresses.

World map - this part of the game is very much like Civilization V and is wonderfully simple and easy to learn. You'll begin with a settler (or a city depending on what options you chose to start with) and your settler will set up your first city, you can choose where. Cities produce gold, production and mana resources and you can build city upgrades and recruit units from them. There are resource structures on the map and if they are inside your city's borders then they give bonuses to gold, production, mana or research. Gold is used to build upgrades in your cities, recruit units and has some functions in diplomacy (yes there's diplomacy with independent cities and other civs), production is very simple - if your city is producing 20 production and a barracks takes 100 production to build, you'll build it in 5 turns. Mana is used to cast spells and knowledge works like production except it's used to research new spells/technologies. Your cities also produce population and grow from small villages to huge metropolises. There's happiness and allignment too - if a city is happy they will throw a party in honour of you which nets you some gold, and alignment is good and evil (and neutral) and is affected by things you do on the map, such as attacking independent cities or letting enemies run when they don't want to fight you. The strategic map is also quite beautiful. Think of it as Civilization V with a fantasy, Lord of the Rings-type feel to it.

The other part of the game is the battle map. You create your armies on the strategic map and when they meet enemies the game loads the battle map. The battle map is turn based and hex based with flanking penalties. You have a variety of units to command, each with very different skills (like necromancers that can raise the dead to fight for you and curse enemies) and your hero can cast spells that he/she has learned. It's all quite easy to learn but takes a bit of time to master.

As I said I think this game is underrated and it's definitely worth buying if you like 4X type games.

reviewText:
An excellent tactical wargame. It plays like a combination of Might & Magic and Civilization, however it differs significantly from the both of them.

First off: do not be fooled, Civilization fans. If you're looking for a fantasy equivalent of Civilization, this isn't going to perfectly scratch that itch. While it does have highly customizable kingdoms (with races and themes to pick from - steampunk elves and druidic dwarves are both possible, for example), the kingdoms themselves serve no purpose except to produce combat units. There is no need to improve tiles, and while civilization happiness is a factor, it's generally not an issue unless enemy empires start using magic to lower happiness within your cities. The biggest thing that hampers it from being 'fantasy Civ' however, is that there is no tech tree and there are no victory conditions other than to defeat your enemies, or attempt to form an Alliance between them.

That said, if you were the sort of Civilization player who preferred scrapping with barbarian tribes and winning the game through domination of your enemies, this game may actually end up being a better alternative. It plays similarly to Civilization V, but it is entirely a wargame. It provides roaming bands of monsters to fight, and small dungeons to explore with your army and recover magical items to equip your heroes with. The independant cities (this game's version of City-States from Civ V) provide quests which can give magical item rewards, and can even reward you with joining your empire, giving you access to unique units such as fey and giants.

The game turns into a Might & Magic-esque tactical RPG when in combat, providing a large grid with terrain to utilize for cover and flanking. Might & Magic players should be happy with what is provided here, though they should keep in mind that battlefields are typically much larger than the chessboard-esque M&M battlefields. Army sizes are also typically much smaller, with most engagements having no more than six units on either side. Only city battles can exceed this limit.

I highly recommend this game to M&M fans, fans of tactical RPGs, and fans of Civilization who enjoy the Domination victory condition. However, Civ players who enjoy nonviolent victory conditions should look elsewhere.

reviewText:
I really like this game and I think it's underrated. It consists of two parts; strategic world map and turn-based battles. I'll briefly explain each one here. There's a campaign mode which is fun but my favourite part of the game is the random map which you can customize the hell out of. There's an incredible amount of options for you to customize your own skirmish game. You can have a very short one with a small map, with huge amounts of resources and starting with large armies, or you can have a large map with lots of civilizations, slow research times, few starting resources (and few resources on the map) and so forth. You can even customize the terrain if you want to take the time, so there are a lot of options to suit your fancy.

You'll choose a race (human, orc, goblin, elf, etc.) and a class (warlord, theocrat, dradnought, sorcerer, etc) for your civilization. Each race has specific strengths and weaknesses and each class is very very different. A warlord civilization for example are focused on strong conventional armies, a dreadnought civilizationis focused on industry and powerful siege engines, a sorcerer civilization is magic based and so on. Your starting hero (which is like a leader of your overall civ and can be used as a general in your armies) will determine the class of your civilization, so choosing a warlord hero will make your civilization a warlord civ, but you can recruit other heroes of other classes as the game progresses.

World map - this part of the game is very much like Civilization V and is wonderfully simple and easy to learn. You'll begin with a settler (or a city depending on what options you chose to start with) and your settler will set up your first city, you can choose where. Cities produce gold, production and mana resources and you can build city upgrades and recruit units from them. There are resource structures on the map and if they are inside your city's borders then they give bonuses to gold, production, mana or research. Gold is used to build upgrades in your cities, recruit units and has some functions in diplomacy (yes there's diplomacy with independent cities and other civs), production is very simple - if your city is producing 20 production and a barracks takes 100 production to build, you'll build it in 5 turns. Mana is used to cast spells and knowledge works like production except it's used to research new spells/technologies. Your cities also produce population and grow from small villages to huge metropolises. There's happiness and allignment too - if a city is happy they will throw a party in honour of you which nets you some gold, and alignment is good and evil (and neutral) and is affected by things you do on the map, such as attacking independent cities or letting enemies run when they don't want to fight you. The strategic map is also quite beautiful. Think of it as Civilization V with a fantasy, Lord of the Rings-type feel to it.

The other part of the game is the battle map. You create your armies on the strategic map and when they meet enemies the game loads the battle map. The battle map is turn based and hex based with flanking penalties. You have a variety of units to command, each with very different skills (like necromancers that can raise the dead to fight for you and curse enemies) and your hero can cast spells that he/she has learned. It's all quite easy to learn but takes a bit of time to master.

As I said I think this game is underrated and it's definitely worth buying if you like 4X type games.

I haven't played Endless legend, but both of these games seemed similar and I had the choice between them.
After some research: the basic difference is probably that Endless Legend is closer to Civilization/ Warlock, and Age of wonders is closer to Heroes of Might and magic.

Age of wonders is a well done 4X game with combat reminiscent of Heroes of Might and Magic, but more strategic depth and world-strategy elements such as city building.

Learning the game properly takes a while, there are a lof of mechanics that only make sense when you research them.

reviewText:
Pretty much all about the warmongering.

Age of Wonders 3 is very much a niche title, even within the 4x game, however, it covers that one niche really well. It's a game about combat, and everything, from the UI, to the city building, to diplomacy itself is entirely in service to the engine of war that this game runs on. Cities are built to build and fund more soldiers. Spells and techs are researched to give an edge in battle or allow you to get more soldiers to bring into battle. Heroes are recruited and trained and killed in the name of war. And they will die, because death comes fast.

The game's selection of Races offer little more than stat changes for your units, granting passives and and a few advantages/disadvantages here and there. Elves have better archers, but are weak to poisons. Goblins have poorer stats, but massive innate poison resist. It's not too important, but definately does shift how you play. As elves, you'll snipe from max range often. As draconians, you won't care much about non-lethal incoming damage.

Classes, namely leader class, determines far more, from your tech tree to your unique units, taking much of what is traditionally race based in other, less warmongering 4x games. Rogues get access to demons, stealth spells, and plenty of tricks to force enemy cities into open revolt. Theocrats tithe for gold like it's going out of style. Dreadnoughts cover massive areas in fiery death with warmachines that outright immune poison and holy damage, but lack counter-attack ability.

Combat is suprisingly quick, due to units being able to destroy eachother in short order. Even levelled heroes are able to be struck down by a few first tier archers focusing fire. As such, mistakes get punished hard.

The game has great customization for the genre, letting you tailor your tech tree, your character and diplomacy screen appearance, hero growth, and make custom equipment to fit the situation.

In summary: I wholeheartedly suggest picking this game up if you're like me and your games of GalCiv2 or Civ V regularly decend into If it moves
date: kill it.". Age of Wonders 3 simply does warmongering so much better
recommended: even if it comes at the cost of alternative victory conditions."

reviewText:
This is not a Civilization V with magic around it, and before buying this game you should have this in mind.
he city managing part id far too simple. You cannot modify the environment around it, all what is left is to choose which building or unit will be next, and if you will use a special resource. It is really a sad point, because everything is ready in the game to do this, so it is obviously a game design choice. Amateurs of city builder will not find this enough.

Actually almost everything is focused around the combat. When enemy units meet, you can choose to resolve automatically or manually. If you choose manually, you then have a turn-based hexagon grid where you deploy your units, and where the deployment zones are functions of the relative locations o the units on the main map when the encounter started. This is not the big thing, but a nice idea. For the rest of the fight, it is dej vu, so I will not go in details. But if you liked Heroes of Might & Magic, you get a lite version of the fighting encounter. In the long run it gets repetitive.

You've got a campaign, which without being a paragon of originality is not bad at all.

The graphics or the main map, are really nice, and the game runs without problems on Linux.

It is hard to either recommend or not this game. I would have preferred a game more about management, but that said, it is not a bad game. If you like turn-based hex-grid battles in a fantasy world, you're a future customer.

reviewText:
I've been a fan of Age Wonders since the first time I played Age of Wonders: The Wizard throne in 5th grade. Since then, Age of Wonders have been the one game I have played continuously throughout middle school, high school, and college. In my opinion, Age of Wonders III is the best of the franchise.

One of the greatest strength of Age of Wonders is its combat. In my opinion, Age of Wonders III is the best of the series in this regard. AowIII introduces new mechanics like flanking which make unit position incredibly important. A smaller army can quickly gain advantage of a stronger army just by utilizing flanking to their best ability.
One of strengths of Aow is the wide variety of units. AoWIII continues this trend. Abilities include dominate, seduce, faerie fire, hurl fire bomb, web, assassinate, hurl boulder, phase (teleport), and much more. These abilities make combat a very engaging and enjoyable.

AoWIII introduces a new class system. These classes include the dreadnought, archdruid, rogue, sorcerer, theocrat, and warlord. Each class as their own set of combat spells, empire upgrades, and units, giving all classes a unique playstyle. As of this review, Triumph is working on a necromancer class. More information on the classes can be found on at http://ageofwonders.com/category/news/.

Like previous games, AoWIII has a variety of races that the player can choose from. The original AowIII has elves, goblins, orcs, humans, dwarves, draconians. Halflings were added in the Golden Realms Expansion. Each race gets an irregular, an archer, an infantry, a cavalry, a pikeman, priest unit, and special final unit. Upon first glance, the races appear to be quite similar. However, there are subtle differences that can end up really impacting one strategy. As an example , consider the archer unit. Elf archers suffer no range penalty, allowing them to do full damage even at distance. Draconian archers laugh firebombs which damage all units in small area. Goblin archers shoot homing mosquitoes which can go through obstacle. Dwarf archers have crossbows which do better damage when they are at close range. Orcs have the worst archers with the worst range; however, they can cause units to bleed which does damage overtime. As one can see, there is a clear difference in the unit abilities.

Along with their class and race, players also choose specializations. These specializations revolve around elemental magic. Player can choose between air, fire, water, earth, creation, and destruction. Each specialization has global and combat spells as well as enchantment and summons. In the original game, there are two non-magic specializations-explorer and expander. These specializations add another level of strategy. When one considers all the race, class, and specializations, there is an astounding number of combinations and strategies to use to destroy one enemies.

In my opinion, AoWIII is the best in the series. Its one of my favorite games. On a final note, the devs are really involved in the community. They really listen to players and incorporate suggestions in the gameplay. Triumph Studios is an amazing studio. They have put a lot of work into this game and continue to do so.

reviewText: This new iteration to the Age of Wonders franchise combines the empire management of the Civilization games and the turn based, hexagonal combat system of the Heroes of Might and Magic series perfectly. The world full of vast biomes and areas to explore has a lot to offer. From sending your armies into a crypt to find a dragon defended by dragonkin and skeletons to sending your army against the Elvish Arch Druid army, only for him to call upon the Forest God to decimate your musketeers. This game offers amazing customization options as well, from creating your character and his looks to choosing his race, his class, his attributes and his spells. All of these options affect how you will play the game. Will you become a Dwarf Arch Druid and heal the land around your empire to reap the awards of a bountiful Harvest? Or will you become a Dragonkin Mage and call down fire and plague and destroy your rival's lands? These spells and skills also affect the combat in the game. Your heroes will have one time spells to use to decimate a particulary powerful creature or even call up a large random creature, which turns out to be a poisonous death adder. Overall, this game is a great source of fun and enjoyment and I can see myself putting many more hours into this game.

reviewText:
A fun, somewhat, competent 4x game that puts a large focus on warfare, Age of Wonders 3 is a great game if you don't look too closely at the seams. In my time playing there are a few concerns that have grown over time and kept this game from being great.

Among these is the enormous focus on warfare. In short, if you are not building towards better units you are doing the wrong thing. Powerful units are paramount for combat of course, but on top of that, there really isn't any other option. Religion? Non-existent. Economy? There are two or three buildings, tops, that will generate any sort of capital. In fact, this makes city placement one of the most important parts of the game; as they dictate what materials you can get at the city.

This brings me nicely to the second problem with the game; enemy AI. The AI in this game is hilarious. They will jump eagerly off their walls during sieges. They will run tword your town only to see that it is a bit large and then do circuits, a bit confused at what they are to do. You will repeatedly see your teammate lose battles because, for some reason, they decided to send a single hero into a group of tier three monsters. Finally, they will neglect to clear monsters from the resource nodes around their cities for literally dozens of turns thereby starving themselves of resources.

And that is what really kills the game for me. I build up a great army (because I have too) to fight opponents too stupid to even keep their resources clear to fund an army that will literally jump from their own battlements.

All of that said, this isn't a terrible game. There is a good sense of involvement in combat, and a great deal of strategy especially due to the flanking system that is missing from other games such as FELH. Those who are expecting a full fledged 4x experience would probably be served better elsewhere, but if you are a fan of tabletop battle games then Age of Wonders Three is a very fun combat simulator for a fraction of the cost. Hopefully the upcoming patch fixes a lot of the issues so that I can change the more negative aspects of this review, but as the game stands it is a 7/10 for me. Buy it only if you are not expecting a pure" 4x experience.

reviewText:
I have been a fan of the Age of Wonders series since the very beginning. The series has been my favorite when it comes to strategy games. I was extremely excited when Triumph Studios announced the third installment of the series. I have watched the status of AOW III develop from the initial announcement up until release.

So, here is my review based on 10 ours of in-game experience. I am extremely impressed with the AI. It is a much greater improvement over the original games. The AI is really taking me for run! I never had much challenge with the AI in the previous games. I like the detailed terrain and atmosphere of the maps/world. The tactical combats are sweet and prettier than the previous games. Also, the tactical AI is much smarter as well. In AOW II SM, I would lure enemies out of the gate in a siege and slaughter them... it doesn't work like that anymore. :D The AI is tough and smarter. The soundtrack is AWESOME! I wish I would have got the deluxe edition just for the soundtrack. I'll have to wait until they release it as DLC. I love how the knights look in AOW III. Their armor shines as they sit on their steeds with their lances; it brings a nice heroic personality. During the 10 hours of in-game experiences I have really enjoyed game. It is fun, exciting, and challenging. I rate it a 9/10 in my opinion.

Here are some of the things I would suggest to improve AOW III. Angels... I really miss the angels from AOW II. Beautiful females, powerful, and celestial beings. They were my favorite unit, and I love how they could only be summoned. AOW III has angelic-like beings called the exalted. However, they just don't fit in the game as the female angels would. Another thing reflecting back upon the angels is that you can also get goblin angels, human angels, dwarf angels, etc... This is due to the new class system in AOW III. Angels, succubus, etc need to be unique, and preferably summoned instead of being standard recruitable creatures. I am hoping Triumph will bring back the angels from AOW II as summons. :) Another thing I would suggest is to bring back the old method of handling flying creatures. In AOW II you needed magic, another flying unit, ranged units, or for the flying unit to attack you in order to deal damage to a flying unit. Based on what I have seen all creatures whether flying or not can hit a flying unit. Lastly, I do prefer the 2d art for heroes and leaders as compared to the 3d stuff (lowest priority).

In conclusion, Age of Wonders III is a solid game that will bring an exciting and challenging experience. I am very happy with my purchase and will continue to support Triumph Studio on further development of Age of Wonders III! 9/10!

I strongly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Do not expect the deep empire management of civilization, this game's strong side is in its combat system, magic system and customization options. You can customize your own avatar and the choice of talents, class and race have significant impact to how your game will play out, allowing to pick a combination most suited to your playstyle. Or just experiment if that's your thing.

As mentioned, the empire management aspects are lacking compared to the competition. Tech tree gets exhausted pretty quickly and it's pretty easy to win by overpowering the AI in early game. On the other hand this kind of setup allows for faster and more 'action' oriented multiplayer matches. However the AI is notoriously bad in terms of diplomacy and still has some bugs that make it easy to beat even on higher difficulties. Add to that an incomplete diplomatic system and the only real option to win the game outside of scripted scenarios is full on military conquest.

The best part however is the combat system. Units are carefully balanced and the combat system allows to win through superior tactics against much more powerful armies... if you know what you're doing. Finding out the various tactics to take down particularly tough units is half the fun. Defending a city surrounded assaulted by a superior foe is suitably satisfying, as is taking out defenders through tactical use of the right units.

Overal: Age of Wonders 3 is a Heroes of Might and Magic meets Civilization in a Tolkien-ish inspired setting. Don't get it for the empire management or you'll be disappointed. Get it for the combat and magic system and it's loads of fun.

reviewText:
Age of Wonders III is my favourite strategy game for a couple of simple reasons:
1: it has the best tactical combat.
2: it has great strategic play, where you need to decide what your priorities are and when to engage.
3: the whole is greater than the parts. The strategic and tactical parts of the game complement each other greatly.

This game is focused on strategy and combat. Everything relates to that, from empire building to leveling your heroes. But don't be afraid, it may be a lot of combat all the time, but the combat is deep enough to be different every time. The game's classes offer you many distinct flavours on how you run your empire, on what kind of army you build, on how your strategies play out. Some classes are more mobile, some classes are better at annoying others, some classes are better at simply building up. The difference does not lie in whether they have units to wage war with, the difference lies in how strong those units are, how they reinforce your armies, how your spells reinforce your armies and wether the class is better at direct battles or sneaking past the front lines.

A bit about empire building: this game is not civilization. The way you develop your cities is not based on what research you unlock and there are NOT a hundred different buildings to choose from. Instead, your building decisions are based on what units you want to unlock, what resources you need more of and how many units you need right NOW. At first, empire building will seem simple compared to other 4x games, but it ties in very well with the other parts of the game.

Dislaimer: I am a total fanboy. I've been part of closed beta testing and met the developers.
Warning: This game has ruined tactical role playing games for me. It has ruined other strategy game tactical combat for me. I find those boring just because I'm used to AoWIII.

Now that I've completed both campaigns, I would have expected to be strongly recommending this game to others.

Unfortunately, I have a real love/hate relationship with this game. Much of the game is great - the grpahics, interface, music and basic gameplay elements. You certainly won't lack for gameplay, the two campaigns took me well over 100 hours to finish, although I never use auto combat so battles made up most of that time.

The hate part comes from the lack of documenation and a few really terrible scenarios in the campaigns. All games should have a manual, especially games this complex, but there is no manual.

Three of twelve scenarios in the campaigns are awful, some of the worst scenario designs I have encountered in decades of playing strategy games, the rest of the scenarios are lots of fun. One is horrible because it has a hidden timer. The other two, the last scenarios in each campaign are horrible because they are mind numbingly frustrating. You have far too many enemies to fight, your basic task is to fight two leaders and attack them with a particular hero. Finding the two leaders is a slow, boring process. It's an idiotic idea which pretty much ruined both campaigns for me. If you are lucky you won't have to play these scenarios, it depends on choices you make earlier in the campaigns.

I do recommend this game if you are willing to put up with some frustration.

reviewText:
I'm going to start off this review with a couple of things:

I've never played AoW 1 or 2
And I'm going to compare it to HoMM3



AoWIII is sorta a fantasy 4X game with very similiar gameplay to the heroes of might and magic series. You have a hero, town(s), and go around raising troops, casting spells, leveling up, exploring the map, and eventually conquering your enemy.


The graphics are pretty nice, it's easy to tell what sort of terrain is what, units are stylistic, and overall the graphics suit the game well.  The music got boring real quick, normally with this kind of game you eventually turn off the music, but I had it off within a few days.

A couple of big differences between this and HoMM are how units are handled. Gone are stacks of 5500 power liches, instead each 'stack' of units on the map can go up to 6 SEPERATE units. This means that a squad of swordsmen is treated as a single unit, and functions the same at 1 HP as it would full. I'm not sure if this good or bad, but that's just how it is.  While you might say battles would be smaller, they can actually be significantly bigger than HoMM, as you can have adjcent stacks on the map help you attack an enemy stack(s).

Battles are also very different (yet) similiar compared to HoMM.  Like HoMM you can cast a spell a turn by your main hero, all your units move in a hex and have different ways to attack and special effects. However, in AoW it's more more tactical, there are flanking attacks that can potentially deny counter attacks and attacks of opportunity against the enemy if they try moving through an enemies' zone of control.

Another big difference between HoMM and AoW is towns. In HoMM towns are usually rare and extremely important objectives for either side, in AoW, you pretty much are able to build towns almost anywhere.  This is an interesting mechanic, but ultimately I found it very boring.  It isn't very difficult to  figure out where to place towns, and as the game goes on I felt I was wasting a lot of time picking what buildings to build in each of my cities, it isn't like civilization either where picking what to build can be a very strategic thing with upsides and downsides (upkeep).

Compared to HoMM, the different races feel overall are way too similiar. Aside from minor stat differences and sometimes damage type differences each race will only have a couple of units that actually stand out from others.

The point fo the above is to try and place an emphasis on hero types. At the start of the map you will select/customize a hero.  You'll choice from a choice of 6 different jobs and select 3 extra magic types.  The job has the biggest effect on how you will play the game. Each one gives you access to the majority of the spells/special units that you will recruit.  This is a very interesting mechanic, however I found it to be somewhat boring in practice.

For example, playing as an archdruid will give you access to Hunters, they're basically bowmen that can charm animals, are better at crossing difficult terrain, and they wear very decorative large masks adorned with feathers.

While playing as a draconian, they fit in perfectly with the rest of the army. However, this is how they look for ALL the races.
Not only that but, they're almost identical no matter what race you have. Why can't goblin hunters focus on traps? Human hunters can be mounted or have tracking dogs with them?  It's even worse when you select a warlord, as two of their special units are bersekers and warkin (basically ogryn from 40k). All bersekers are bald. Even high elves. And they look absolutely .

If they couldn't differentiate the units in abilities due to balancing issues, at least they could make the units thematically look like they belong to the faction, something HoMM did very well.

Another minor problem I have with the game is there isn't a quick access for your different heroes you might have hired, you have to bring up the overview panel then switch to your armies. This wouldn't be a problem, except for that you can't have the overview panel up at the same time as your city build orders, which is a problem, because over the course of the game you'll have both a large amount of cities and units.

Additionally, the neutral units available for fighting and recruiting/prizes feel very small, it might just be because I played HoMMIII with WoG and that offered quite a good selection. Another thing HoMM had that AoW lacks are interesting items to loot for your hero or neutral unit hexes that let you hire them. While there are a couple of special town types like dragon they function a little differently



I really want to like this game. Its combat is fun, and has some really great mechanics dragged down by citiy micomanagement, race diversity, and some lazy copy\pasting unit designs

Edit:

Since there's been two expansions for this game, they've been absolutely great. They did a pretty good job at giving each race more unique abilities, and added more neutral units and items. I don't like necromancers though, the mechanics they have seem so gamechanging compared to the other hero classes.

reviewText:
Age of Wonders 3 is a turn-based fantasy 4X strategy game focused on combat rather than empire building. As such, it has more in common with Master of Magic and Heroes of Might and Magic III than with Civilizations 5.

The base game provides two different and quite long campaigns featuring branching paths and different endings, a few pre-generated scenarios, and a random map generator with a lot of map and game options to customize your games to your liking.
Multiplayer is present and alive with the possibility to play with people who own the GOG version, meaning the community is not divided.

You start a game by customizing your leader by choosing his race and class between 6 different races and 6 different races, amounting to 36 different initial combinations, with each race and class having distinct spells and characteristic, providing them different optimal gameplay while still being homogeneous enough to keep things balanced. To further specialize your leader, you can also chose between 8 specialization options, such as Water adept, Fire adept, Explorer, etc.

The game is extremely fun to play and the combat system is excellent in both concept and execution. Add to that different units and spells interacting together dynamics and you get really epic battles that never feel like they are dragging on.

Golden Realms Expansion:
The first expansion pack adds one new race, two new specializations, a new campaign, new scenarios, new units, new spells, new mechanics, and new map options, turning the game from great to amazing.

Highly recommended!!!

reviewText:
Should you buy Age of Wonders 3? Yes, but there's a catch.

ABOVE AVERAGE for its price

The game is visually impressive with a lot of love and care taken to make the game the best it could possibly be. The problem is, the game lacks... ambition. The combat is really all there is to the game and while its fulfilling early on, it tends to drag on late game. You'll spend hours clearing the resource points of monsters and enemy camps to build a safe and sprawling empire only to realize that your empire is just to feed your warmachine, nothing else. At which its very easy to proclaim yourself the winner because what reward is there to finishing a solo game?

Which leads to the other problem, multiplayer. 4x strategy games are really meant for multiplayer matches. Its a wonderful race to see who can build what faster, stronger, and diplomatic better. However AoW 3 doesn't lend itself well to MP games because of time and lack of any real substantial diplomacy.
-time, essentially you either sacrifice time to enjoy the game and its combat the way its meant to be played, or you turn the quick autobattles on and skip over the big tactical portion of the game. Its a lose lose either way.
-Diplomacy is lacking because there is no real benefit to peace other than a secure border but, who's to say your peaceful neighbor won't just backstab you? As there is no consequence for breaking your word, no morale penalties, no reduced gold income or productivity, nothing. The flip side is also true, no economical advantages to being at peace :(

Despite all that its still a good game and I enjoyed very much of it, its just sad to see so much potential fizzle out.

+Graphics, a very rich, visually appealing game

+Tactical combat is very satisfying

+-Replay value is there, but late game becomes tedious management and busy work... I've yet to finish a single random scenario

-No tech tree, research randomness in a strategy game is a bit disappointing

-Good luck finding a rewarding mp experience for a game that is by design, not meant for multiplayer

-DLC is a bit disapointing

reviewText:
I never played the original, but I loved Age of Wonders II. So coming into this as a fan of AoW2, my expectations were high, and I honestly wasn't disappointed. I love this game for so many reasons, from leader creation and customization to the way your race tints the special units your class affords you. The game is visually beautiful and fairly well-paced, and the random map generator has always delivered a world I genuinely enjoyed exploring and conquering.

AoW3 suits a number of play styles and victory conditions, all of which you can toggle on or off. The battles require thought and planning a little more than raw power. A number of weak units can take down a smaller number of more powerful units if you position everyone correctly and use just the right spells at the right times. I get a genuine sense of pride every time I successfully bring down a powerful enemy army.

There are, of course, a few things that could stand to be improved. I'd like more customization options as far as hair is concerned, and there are some lighting issues and minor clipping problems on some of the unit models. However, all of these issues are superficial and very easy to overlook. I don't find they detract from my experience at all.

Excellent game if you enjoy fantasy, strategy or 4X games, and an absolutely superb game if you enjoy all three!

reviewText:
I have 342 hours into the game as of this review, and have only played single player.  This is easily the most played game in my Steam library. (Skyrim comes in at 2nd, with about 275 hours as of this review.  And whatever is in 3rd place is so far back, it can't even see the dust from these two.)  I find this funny, since I almost passed on buying AoW3.

This is a deep game, which took me about 60 hours just to feel like I was getting the feel of all the possibilities.

The intro campaign got a bit tedious by about the 4th chapter, so I jumped into random maps.  Very enjoyable!  Just about anything you can think of is customizable, including your leader's race, specialty, and appearance; to map type, size and features (the map can be dangerous and rewarding... at the same time); to number of heros allowed and their max levels...  Oh yes, and the number, skill and specialties of your A.I. opponents are individually tweakable.  Basically, after you haved played a bit, each random map is a game you can fully and intelligently customize to optimize the challenge and maximize your own enjoyment.

The strategy level is turn-based or semi-real time (selectable) and the combat is turn-based.  Decisions you make at the strategy/map level greatly influence numbers and capabilities of troops you field.  The tactical combat is deep.  With the right skills and knowledge, you can defeat far superior opponents (or vice versa: you can get your fanny kicked by an inferior opponent).  Your opponents are scalable in toughness, and total defeat is definitely an option.  Making the right decisions at both the strategic and tactical levels makes for very satisfying play.

A lot of attention was given to the audio and visual experience.  The map and game pieces are beautiful.  Every troop has its own unque sounds and animations for different actions, including combat.  There is a bit of an RPG element --> Heros and leaders get stronger if you cultivate them, have many different capabilities, based on class, and really can make a big difference in battle outcomes.

reviewText:
In an age of expensive, flashy, superficial games, here is one that stands apart.

I never played AoW2, but I played the original and it's one of my favorite classic games, right up there with Age of Empires: Age of Kings, and AoW3 is true to its roots.

Newer games tend to shed the characteristics that made their predecessors great in favor of aspects that make good trailers and build extraordinary hype, only to fall flat on release when everybody finds out how shallow they are. Not this one. AoW3 delivers a deep experience that you can approach from a number of different ways: there's campaigns, scenarios, multiplayer--and random map, which is by far the best feature.

For The Elder Scrolls II: Daggerfall, Bethesda randomly generated a world the size of Great Britain. Once. AoW3 does that every time you start a new random map. Yeah, they're not really comparable, but the point is made. No two random maps are the same. A single, 8-player, extra large random map will get you your money's worth out of AoW3, then you'll start a new one as a different race, different class, different school of magic, and you'll do it again and it'll be all-new. You'd better quit reading reviews and get started.

reviewText:
If you like 4x type games this is a good one, if you like rpgs.... well if you like 4x its a good one. But seriously a good solid game. If you want a Civ type game is a fantasy setting this is one of the best ones out there. Lots of customization and depth. Very detailed character creation and great mechanics for customizing the play to your own style. Want to sneak up on your enemies? Smite them from afar? Smash them with giant machines? Blast them with terrible magics? Negotiate with them (coward... jk)?  you can do it here.

First the basics-

Graphics- immersive and well executed, solid if not flashy. 8/10

Gameplay- Easy to play and learn. It has good depth when you want to dive down into the mechanics. 9/10

Music/SF- Nothing jarring or off putting, but nothing epic either. Always switched to my own tunes fairly quickly. 5/10

Content- Lots of good stuff on the map, fun to explore. Plenty of scenarios and several main campaigns, but no really engaging stories, I find I go to randoms maps as I come back to the game. as a RPG 4/10, as a 4X 9/10.

Ok so now lets look at this as a 4x-

eXplore- This is probably my favorite part of the game. Many and various encounters on the map lead to a lot of variety in gameplay. This has a feel like Heros of M&M 3, with maps full of goodies.

eXpand- Not really part of the game. Oh sure you grow your city and maybe build a couple more, but there is no real benefit or mechanic for the massive empire in this game.

eXploit- Magic always makes this fun. I really enjoy the way it lets you manipulate the environment of the game. Lots of ways to customize your character to fit your style.

eXterminate- This is were this game shines. It has good combat mechanics that make each battle different, but also allows you to turn things over to the AI when you get too bogged down late game. Every race and every class bring their own unit types and style to combat, making it extremely variable and challenging.

In the end I recommend this game. If you saw RPG and came for that turn around now, but otherwise a good game and worth the price.

reviewText:
Age of Wonders III is a very combat centered turn based strategy game with a fantasy setting where magic can turn the tide of battle just as much as steel.

Many people try to compare this game to Civilization V, in respect to that I respond.

Age of Wonders III does use a city based system in part to produce an army and procure territory to gain resources. However, in the defense of that mechanic there are options of using Summoned units, Inns, and rewards gained from battle or clearing quests to earn an army. Some of those features are clearly not in Civilization V.

For me the better game series to compare to comes from the Real Time Strategy games known as Warcraft (Age of Wonders III) and Starcraft (as opposed to Civ V). If you ever played Warcraft III you might remember the times of having a Hero unit that could (and often did) become more powerful than most other units of your army, sometimes more powerful than a small handful of units on their own.

Age of Wonders III uses a Hero system in a similar concept as Turn Based Strategy game. Your heroes level up, earn abilities. You can quest, battle, or even forge your own gear (non-campaign on the forging bits) for your heroes to use in combat. Heroes can die, and when they die they drop all the items they had on them. But you do not have to say goodbye to them forever because there are ways in game to revive them, powerful revival magic (instead of hero shrines from Warcraft 3).

TLDR: Ultimately, if you play the game for a single player experience you will find enjoyment in the campaigns, and for a time in the solo scenarios, random maps, and various play styles. However, combat will quickly become tedious and repetative. Against the A.I. I recommend using Auto-Battle most the time, but the true glory of the Manual Battles is when you can fight against a Human Opponent using either Online, LAN, or Hotseat as a multi-player turn based game.

Quick Notes:

- I recommend Turn Based with a 3 minute turn timer for small groups.
(turn timer incase people forget to hit end turn)

- There is the option to use Simultaneous turns
(but it can feel choppy, and it can lead to logisitic problems for battle prep on the strategic map)

reviewText:
My favourite 4x game....to me, beats CIV5 despite having fewer 'nations'.

Characterful and charming game that uses randomised elements to keep everything fresh each time.

Even just looking at the randomized starting positions, there are so many ways to approach each of your games and this all has a knock on effect to how your progression and wars play out. Diplomacy is relatively well implemented, but it does still tend to edge towards a huge us vs them war in the end unless you create fixed teams or try really hard at keeping peace with various factions.

The turn based combat works really well and makes sieges especially interesting.

Highly recommended and definitely buy both of the expansions; they add even more awesome stuff to an already great game!

reviewText:
Ok...before I begin, I must say that AoW3 is my first foray into the age of wonders series.

The closest equivilent game I have played is Fallen Enchantress.

That said, on with the show.

The game starts off with good veriaty and a beautiful visual.  You can pick from 6 races with 6 classes for each, each one a little different.  You also get the opportunity to make your own leader using any of the races as a template, each with a modifiable look and modifiable name.

The gameplay of the game is fun.  As well as your fellow leaders running around, there is the independents, which are all the non-aligned units, ranging from monsters and bandits, to neutral towns that you can either conquer/annihilate for the lulz or convince to join your empire by paying them gold.  Doing this is quite fun despite the ease to simply buy up the cities and also allows you to, with patience to get access to ALL the races for yourcurrent class...or you can be a evil bugger and forcibly migrate your race to these cities.

This brings me to my first little niggle regarding the AI.  The AI players work with you...unless you do things that  them off and man are they picky.

They take notes of EVERYTHING you do and it doesn;t take much to upset them to the point that they will launch war after war against you.  While they will forget about these, it takes a LONG time.  In my main game, I noted how my one war against a enemy had given a -1200 rating that would last for nearly 130 turns.

This also brings up a AI problem I noted regarding these, which involved me getting a war penalty despite the fact that the other guy started it.  That is a bug that needs to be looked at in the least.

The next part, the combat.  This is similar to Fallen enchantress in that it is a turn based fight on a special map.  Each fight takes place between the two enemies on a hex and the units in the surrounding one.  However, again, evern on dumbest setting, the AI seems suspiciously competent, sending overwelming force against their chosen target.  There is regularly little warning of an attack, meaning you'll lose at least one city before you can get a peace treaty established, which is easy to do, surprisingly.

AI players will happily take a peace treaty, regardless of how well their war is going with you.  While I welcome this given how war happy my neighbours are in my current game, it is a little boring and easy to avoid a war thats going badly.

Units, research and spells are next.  Like Fallen enchantress, you get to research a series of abilities/spells and units, ranging from mounted units to the local racial units depending on what race city you have up to, the kick  juggernort 'land-ship' which is basically a 'I Win' unit.  You also get a nice selection on hero units, the cap of which you can limit.

Spells however are also pretty good, and are unique to your chosen magic abilities and your class.  They have good veriaty, many have useful impact and are fun (the dreadnoughts 'mana core' nuke is just fun and a great mifddle finger to give a enemy thats overwelming you), ranging from the terraforming abilities, in-battle attacks unique to your heroes and world improvement spells such as the dreadnoughts 'supress nature; that removes all terrein penalties.

However, my biggest problem is with the story campaign.  The difficulty there is .  Half way into the FIRST MISSION...I was swarm attacked by about 30 units out no nowhere by a enemy I hadn;t even met.  This NEEDS to be patched ASAP but is not too big a problem in the long term of things

In conclusion, AoW3 is a great game that sits up there with the civilization and Fallen enchantress series's.  It has some bugs but its only just been released and I have no doubt that Triumph Studioes will fix these problems and game balance issues.

If you like the sid meier games and Galactic Civilization games, you'll love this game too.

Final rating:  9/10

It loses a point due to the unbalanced AI.

reviewText:
Just Another Review.
Well so I bought this game because everyone who has played a kings bounty, disciples, heroes of might and magic?, civ and etc type of turn based strategy game will get the itch to play another if they discover they like it.

Ive put around 20-30 hours into this game single player only (commonwealth) and I was pleasently suprised. After I wrapped around the controls which for whatever reason seemed backwards (left and right mouse buttons would be vise versa if i made things lol), I got pretty into the game and keep coming back. Although I could say a lot more, I am going to summarize things in bullet form as best i can and I will likely miss some things:

Thinks I think that could be improved:

-The research tree is still rather baffling if you want to plan ahead or unlock certain things unless you have played a lot. If it was set up like in civilization with some kind of flow chart it would be a lot easier to prioritize.

-Combat animations are kinda crumby with the units (i'm just whining nothing that harms the game)

-The hero cannot die clause. Warcraft 2 all over again. In the campaign you basically just keep your hero in the back away from harm and cast spells unless you want him focus'ed by the AI and to reload your save. Personally I think the hero's need more durability else they essentially just play a support role for most of the fight, cuz when they die everything stops. You aren't going to siege a city without those wonderful buffs they give all the units in the army pack nor will you go and explore ruins/want to fight if a hero isn't milking exp.

-The exp system, it should essentially award everyone in the army attacking or not. Win a battle: gain most exp, lose a battle: hero gets some exp everyone else is dead lol, Run from a battle get no exp (since running could be abused). I essentially just have hero use a ranged ability to kill off whatever i can (safely) as to net more exp.

-The AI during sieges, if you have 2 trebuchets you can basically funnel all the enemies through a narrow hole in the wall, ive beat a few very likely defeat" situations abusing this with a very small army. If the enemy is more numerous then you past a certain extent they should just bum rush you out the gates and cut u off instead of hole up and get picked off.

-Spellcasting seems kind of wonky
date:
losing your hero for casting oil skin almost doesnt seem worth it... some spells should perhaps count as your cast and not your hero turn and the more powerful will take both...

Things I dont understand yet....:

-I still have no idea the use of teraforming whatsoever. Ive never encountered any situation where i would want to change my land type. Nor have unhappy people

reviewText:
Fallen Enchantress, Eat your heart out.

This 4X Fantasy game allows for a deep level of customization that captures the creativity of Fallen Enchantress while providing a more aesthetically pleasing, polished experience. Diplomatic and overworld gameplay remains similar to the Civilization series, while not quite as robust. It does make up for it with its level of creative control.

Create your own civilization leader from a host of classes and racial combinations. Both your class and race affect the type of units your empire will have access to. If you play a rogue, depend on having stealth units, assassins and the like. Play a dreadnaught? Youll have rifleman and steam tanks. A warlord? How does having a legion of berserkers sound? While you cant directly modify individual units like fallen enchantress, the sheer vareity at your disposal makes that irrelavant.

If youre looking for a high fantasy themed civilization style 4X game with RPG elements, look no further.

As with every 4X game, this one has a distinct love of two of them, eXploit and eXterminate. Let's start with that.

The command, unlike some other games, namely Fallen Enchantress, which is the main comparrison I'll be making, is rather dull. It takes about 25-70 turns, depending on what's in its domain, to complete the city entirely, and each city has to make that trek and the only real thing that changes it is the Raze, Plunder and Migrate options for each city, which is a nice touch, since each race has its own benefits.  Compared to Fallen Enchantress, though, the cities feel... Dull. It's the same path each time, and once you get all your class specific units, the entire war units tree is useless. One main problem I have with it, and this is a personal quipe, but oh well, is that the cities just suddenly... get taken over. Anything above a city I'm practically yelling at the screen with the general rage when a group of SCOUT units, which literally are so easy to kill that a tier four takes 1 damage to them, takes over your throne city/any other metropolis. That was a major turn off for me.

Now, onto the war section. The combat is probably the most fun I've had in a 4X. It's really slick, it carries weight, and the seiges are fun. The general feel of the units are amazing, with specific combinations practically winning seiges and battles. The units all have unique rolls on the battlefield, some are tanks that don't deal much damage, or a Give them the plague!" units that makes whatever they attack weaker. And one of my favorite

reviewText: There have been a lot of new entries in the Fantasy 4X Strategy genre in recent years. For a long time though it seems like the genre has peaked with classics like Master of Magic, and Heroes of Might an Magic 3. The latter being a personal favorite of mine. Now after a long wait we are getting games that are really good again like Fallen Enchantress, and Warlock. Age of Wonders 3 however is probably my new favorite out of all of them.\n\nYou can tell when playing it that the designer has probably played all of the games I mentioned above, and more. The game takes many good ideas of those titles incorporating in with some good ideas of it's own. The result feels really solid. Almost like a greatest hits album of the genre. It's important to know though that the title is focused more on the competitive element. This isn't an empire builder like Civ where you can sit in a corner, and focus on culture or something. It's built as a war game. Those that go into understanding that, and craving it will have a better time.
