reviewText:
I give this game a 8 out of 10.

The game reminds you strongly of Heroes of Might and Magic.  Your character travels the map, explores locations, and takes controll of resource points.  Combat isn't as developed as HoMM.  Your troops are deployed randomly and your find yourself really missing being able to line up your troops as you see fit.  Also lacks the variety of HoMM's tactical combat options for your units.

The game also strongly reminds you of Elemental Fallen enchantress.  You can send out units to colonize and expand your realm.  Building different buildings expands the zone of controll for each city.  It falls a little short of the Elemental comparison with the lack of RPG elements and the variety of items to equip your character with.

The storyline for the two campaigns is decent, the single female voice actress does a great job, but you find yourself wishing for a few animated cutscenes to spice things up.  Each mission is more or less the same.  Build up your troops and take out your enemies.  It can get a little stale after about 20 hours though.

reviewText: This game is great whether you're a fan of the series, a fan of strategy games, or just a newcomer to these kind of games. Learning the gameplay might take a tad bit but when you start playing you'll find yourself bargaining time away just so you can play one more turn. The single player is pretty much where most people start, in order to learn the game mechanics and the game does that pretty well, by the time I got to the thrid level I was already building proper armies, upgrading cities, and destroying other empires. The game's AI is smart even on easy and you will find them hitting your weak points if you underestimate them while the hardest difficulty pushes you to use everything in your power to win, also although you can build alliances with the AI it is actually very hard to do so because most of the time they're in it for themselves but then again so are we so peace most of the time will not be in your options. You can also fight the battles yourself on a field but after awhile I just kept using auto battle unless it was a battle that I needed to be won then I took control but do know that one level can take a long time to complete because you'll be managing your cities, planning strategies for the future, or something else which will take time unless you're blitzing all the time. The music really is well made, the graphics are great, the multiplayer is fun and in a nutshell this game is very entertaining

reviewText:
The game is a winner, as far as I have played it so far. I have always been a fan of strategy, whether it be turn-based or real-time, but also have like many other genres too. I have many games that compete for my limited game time, but this one is winning hands-down at the moment.

While there are some definite 'Heroes of Might and Magic' parallels, it feels much more holistic. The tactical fighting is great, and just gets better the more I learn about the units and the mechanics. The leveling system for each unit is great, and makes you really try to keep the unit alive, granting better powers and giving each experienced unit a sense of being less 'replaceable' by the next newly produced unit. This means that rather than sending them to their doom just to finish the battle faster, or being too careless or clumsy, you really want to make sure they get involved (to get more xp), but keep them from sacrificing themselves for a worthless cause.

The Heroes are great, and with so much customisation as they level up, it leaves you forever wishing you had more points to throw at their skills. This also makes it juicily special when they level up. And, even better is that it can really make a difference to the battles, whether it be the spells that enhance your 'shock troopers' to take and dish-out a heap of punishment, or enhancing your hero so they themselves become a mobile game-changer wherever they tread.

The city development is interesting too. It does not boast the most exhaustive list of buildings, but in the early-mid game it promotes the development of a city so that it specialises in one or two troop types. I really like this because it means you can plan your overall strategy with more effectiveness. Including thinking about how to get your slow-moving troops to the enemy - do you build them in the close cities, or build roads between cities, or keep each city more generic and have lower level or lower tiered troops. Lots of delicious approaches.

Another big plus is the ability to play offline. Which is great as I often travel. Cloud auto-saves can also help me progress on either my PC or laptop.

If you like strategy, and multiple approaches to victory - then this game is for you. Heroes class and race make a difference, and the constant difficult choice of which spells and skills to choose is fantastic. Runs surprisingly well on low specs too.

Cons - can't save the game mid-way through a battle, music is not amazing (but who really plays these games for the music).

Please enjoy!

reviewText:
At first I did not know what to make of this game. But I felt intrigued enough to keep playing. Then I slowly started unraveling the intricacies and the secrets and I got absolutely hooked.

The biggest draw for me, is the degree of customisation it offers. There are literally dozens of combinations of race/class/specialisation combined with random maps which are quite configurable, and a lot of different tweaks for each game map. One game you might be playing a Frostling Sorcerer with master destruction and rain death (and stun) on your foes, next game a Dwarf Theocrat rising from the caves below the surface to conquer everything, specializing in wild magic with unpredictable results. Then a Tigran Warlord Grey Guard, bashing down all opposition. Then later you might revisit the Frostling sorcerer, but be lucky enough to have a building that makes your Ice Queens practically immortal (if you end up winning the fight) inside your domain.

What I'm getting at, is not only are all of these options extremely fun to play around with and figure out interesting and powerful combinations, but they offer a replayability rarely seen in games.

Really this game is amazing and you should check it out if you are a fan of Turn Based Strategy games. If only HoMnM games were half this good these days...

reviewText:
One of the best games of this genre since Heroes of Might and Magic II... seriously amazing!

It follows the same style where you pick a main hero who has a race and a class, with three specialties (Spell Masteries, traits etc).  You build cities and go exploring and BATTLING.  Yeah, the game is all about the combat so if you're looking for something like CIvilization you will be sorely disappointed with this one.

The combat is excellent and strategic.  Units can level up during battles, and eventually, can become quite strong if they've been with you since the beginning of the game.  The game has flanking, attacks of opportunity, line of sight bonuses and penalties (however, no friendly fire with ranged attack, so that's a plus), Overwhelm, Status Effects, Special Movement Types... I don't know what more you could ask for in the combat part.

In terms of things that aren't combat like city management, etc... Yeah - it's limited.  Diplomacy leaves me scratching my head and there's no options to make other players necessarily like you, just peace treaties or alliance proposals.  City buildings basically fall into either resource production (for that glorious army you're building) or unit recruitment buiildings so it's easy enough to get into.

It may be rather simple, but that's how Heroes of Might and Magic II was and man if this isn't the spirtual succesor to that game I don't know what is.

reviewText:
This game is very complex, it doesn't compromise its complexity trying to streamline it (like Civilization: Beyond Earth which I recently played and didn't like). This game, instead, celebrates its complexity by finely balancing it and making everything in the game be worth using, even Tier 1 units which in nearly every other game (including its predecessors) become obsolete by mid-game.
The turns play fast, battle auto-resolving works acceptably well and actually simulates the battles instead of making an oddball calculation based on numbers. You have the option to make your heroes survive auto-resolved battles if you win them (to avoid the strong annoyance of the CPU suiciding your heroes), thus relieving you of a lot of unwanted micromanagement.
The tactical battles in the game are detailed, very enjoyable, and also optional! since the auto-resolve feature plays fine. You can replay auto-resolved battles to learn the game's complex tactical combat by watching the computer (I learned partly that way).

The graphics, music and interface of the game are excellent. If you play with low detail graphics you may have Age of Wonders II flashbacks  =)  specially with antialiasing off. You can run this game in moderately old hardware (something other modern games can't).

Excellent Turn-Based Strategy Game, a personally refreshing sight after failures like Civilization: Beyond Earth and Heroes VI. Get it on a discount sale if you're hesitant. I'm sure you'll be buying the expansions rather soon  =)

( The expansions added new victory conditions and even more variety to an already spicy game. The base victory mode in random scenarios in this game is conquest. Check the reviews )

reviewText:
A 4x fantasy game that has all the elements you could wish for, allowing it to make a real challenge at being arguably the best in its genre. But does it live up to its sparkle ?

If you're old enough to remember Master of Magic, then you will know the precursor game that AoW III has built itself on. If you're not old enough, then AoW is a game of the same family as Warlock, or any of the fantasy mods for Civ. A turn based fantasy game you will spend your time exploring a map, expanding your empire, exploiting resources and finally exterminating your enemies. A 4x to the core. Whilst there have been innumerable takes on this formula, AoW III promises to bring all these things together with a decent rub of polish and just enough depth to really please the 4x audience.

And in many ways the game does just that - a nice tactical combat system that brings depth to the strategic map manoeuvres without overstaying its welcome. A diverse and interesting number of resources to exploit. Bucketfuls of different army units and racial types. And so on.

But despite all this, and despite it looking great, the game has some flaws. And when you get to playing it, those flaws really start to bite.

The first flaw is the simultaneous move implementation. Turn based games can turn into a tedious snore fest if they opt for a me go you go type mechanic. Fortunately in this day and age such things are rare ( with the exception of the woeful coding of Warlock ), but in AoW III the simultaneous movement has a hitch. Everything and everyone moves simultaneously - players, AI kingdoms, independents. And the AI has a beautifully machine like grief play style where it can wait for you to make a single move somewhere, before rolling forward its units to sneak in the back door and take that town from you.

Woops.

So maybe you shouldn't move out of that town. At all. Ever. A bizarre nervouse mexican stand off ensues where the AI stares you down waiting for you to misclick or even just investigate a passing army before rushing in to capitalise. And it's no good clicking once you've taken that step - particularly if you are playing in a multiplayer network game - as the whole thing then lags and chugs busy processing its own fabulously griefing move whilst your frantic clicks can sit and wait.

In practice the simultaneous movement with AIs on the field of play quickly becomes irritating - and it starts to warp play into some neurotic twitch fest. It's not the first game to implement this type of nervous who clicks first simultaneous play, but here, combined with a simplistic IS IT OK FOR ME TO ATTACK NOW" state AI
date:
it can often prove enormously frustrating.

Fortunately simulaneous movement is optional.

Non simultaneous movement then goes back to the tedious me go you go turn order. But at least you can go out explore something and be home for tea without the griefing AI kicking your door down mid journey. Well. Mostly.

The second flaw to the game is that towns don't have an implicit defence. That is to say

reviewText:
If you're a fan of the Age of Wonders series you probably already own this. If you don't, what are you waiting for?
It's good, don't worry!


If you're completely new to this francise however, this choice is a more difficult one. This game is hexbased, turbased, fantasy, strategy game with rpg elements. If you didn't run aways screaming at those words, this game may be for you. The genre itself is a bit niche, but within it's genre, it's very good. It features:

-  a very indepth combat system
- quite deep city building (though no where near CIV5 standards)
- Incredible addictive and timesinking gameplay (very high replayabillity)
- Cool graphics
- Unique classes (they differ a lot in terms of strategy and gameplay)
- continuous updates (golden gates is already out, now we are waiting for the undead to arrive)

On the downside however

- Steep learningcurve
- Difficult AI (which is simultaniously a good thing, the ai is pretty smart)
- Uninteresting story (highfanasty qualms, order of quartidoudle, counsil of ziyrlotsofletters blahblah)
- slow pacing (one lvl from a campaign will require mutiple hours if not a few days to complete.
- the morality system feels iffy and doesn't add much.

tl;dr: All in all I think it's a very good game if you're not scared away by long sessions, difficult AI and high fantasy drama

reviewText: This title reminds me of the Heros of Might and Magic series and has many similarities to it.  Fans of it will likely enjoy Age of Wonders as well.  It improves on the familiar formula with ideas from other strategy games such as cities which expand over time and generate income from resources withing their spheres of infulence.  Unlike Heroes you are able to estlablish new cities on the map as well as fortifications and road networks.  Armies made up completely of flying units are able to cross lakes and mountains and terraforming spells can improve your territory or ruin your enemy's, effecting the morale of cities, which have terrian preferences and dislikes depending on their racial characteristics.  A unified research system unlocks new spells, units, traits, abilities, etc.  Like heroes the map has an overworld and underworld providing difficult stategic oppertunities for surprise attacks and shortcuts.  Unlike Heros, multiple armies in adjactent hexes can participate in the same battle for epic scale combat and seige warfare.  Multiple unique army leaders can band together into a fighting unit along with expendable military units in groupings of up to six, and will fight alongside their troops in battle as cavalry units capable of both ranged and melee attacks as well as spells and special abilities.  Leaders also gain experience and can be improved with increased stats and other perks upon leveling up.  Familiar fantasy races compete in this setting such as Elves, Orcs, Draconians, Dwarves, and Undead, amoung others.  Two campains are available with the game as well as custom maps and multiplayer options.

reviewText:
I don't even know where to begin to describe the high amount of production quality and really how deep this game is. To start its fair to say this game is the offspring of Civilization 5 and XCOM: Enemy Unknown all set in a fantasy realm with magic and different races. You have large scale geographically diverse maps that allow you to build individual cities and armies to form a massive empire. Strategy and tactics have to be considered as all combat is done in standalone battlefields, not the overworld. The tile of the defender determines the actual battlefield; I was on attacked on a bridge, outnumbered 2:1 and I won the fight because I funneled the attackers onto this narrow bridge and let them have it. Age of Wonders 3 merges the best things about Civilization 5 and tactical games like XCOM to make a game that really reminds of you the choices you've made and the paths you lead.

Pros:
- Stunning graphics
- In depth tactical battles
- Intelligent AI
- Varied multi-tier units and spells/abilities
- Robust leader customization
- Two campaigns; divided by difficulty and are very lengthy
- Features Underground tunnels/caves to add an extra layer to the map
- Alt+Tab friendly :)

Cons
- Steep learning curve, most advanced concepts aren't taught in the campaign until you've learned them the hard way
- DRM online only, have to sign up for a third-party account to play
- May take over your entire day if not careful

Final Score = 90% / 100%

- quite deep city building (though no where near CIV5 standards)
- Incredible addictive and timesinking gameplay (very high replayabillity)
- Cool graphics
- Unique classes (they differ a lot in terms of strategy and gameplay)
- continuous updates (golden gates is already out, now we are waiting for the undead to arrive)

On the downside however

- Steep learningcurve
- Difficult AI (which is simultaniously a good thing, the ai is pretty smart)
- Uninteresting story (highfanasty qualms, order of quartidoudle, counsil of ziyrlotsofletters blahblah)
- slow pacing (one lvl from a campaign will require mutiple hours if not a few days to complete.
- the morality system feels iffy and doesn't add much.

tl;dr: All in all I think it's a very good game if you're not scared away by long sessions, difficult AI and high fantasy drama

reviewText: This title reminds me of the Heros of Might and Magic series and has many similarities to it.  Fans of it will likely enjoy Age of Wonders as well.  It improves on the familiar formula with ideas from other strategy games such as cities which expand over time and generate income from resources withing their spheres of infulence.  Unlike Heroes you are able to estlablish new cities on the map as well as fortifications and road networks.  Armies made up completely of flying units are able to cross lakes and mountains and terraforming spells can improve your territory or ruin your enemy's, effecting the morale of cities, which have terrian preferences and dislikes depending on their racial characteristics.  A unified research system unlocks new spells, units, traits, abilities, etc.  Like heroes the map has an overworld and underworld providing difficult stategic oppertunities for surprise attacks and shortcuts.  Unlike Heros, multiple armies in adjactent hexes can participate in the same battle for epic scale combat and seige warfare.  Multiple unique army leaders can band together into a fighting unit along with expendable military units in groupings of up to six, and will fight alongside their troops in battle as cavalry units capable of both ranged and melee attacks as well as spells and special abilities.  Leaders also gain experience and can be improved with increased stats and other perks upon leveling up.  Familiar fantasy races compete in this setting such as Elves, Orcs, Draconians, Dwarves, and Undead, amoung others.  Two campains are available with the game as well as custom maps and multiplayer options.

reviewText:
I don't even know where to begin to describe the high amount of production quality and really how deep this game is. To start its fair to say this game is the offspring of Civilization 5 and XCOM: Enemy Unknown all set in a fantasy realm with magic and different races. You have large scale geographically diverse maps that allow you to build individual cities and armies to form a massive empire. Strategy and tactics have to be considered as all combat is done in standalone battlefields, not the overworld. The tile of the defender determines the actual battlefield; I was on attacked on a bridge, outnumbered 2:1 and I won the fight because I funneled the attackers onto this narrow bridge and let them have it. Age of Wonders 3 merges the best things about Civilization 5 and tactical games like XCOM to make a game that really reminds of you the choices you've made and the paths you lead.

Pros:
- Stunning graphics
- In depth tactical battles
- Intelligent AI
- Varied multi-tier units and spells/abilities
- Robust leader customization
- Two campaigns; divided by difficulty and are very lengthy
- Features Underground tunnels/caves to add an extra layer to the map
- Alt+Tab friendly :)

Cons
- Steep learning curve, most advanced concepts aren't taught in the campaign until you've learned them the hard way
- DRM online only, have to sign up for a third-party account to play
- May take over your entire day if not careful

Final Score = 90% / 100%

reviewText:
To those who love games like Final Fantasy Tactics, Tactics Ogre, XCOM, etc..., I would highly recommend this game. It takes the core elements of great tactics style RPGs, and throws them inside a slightly simplified empire building game a la Civilization V.

I can acknowledge that the strategic portion of the game lacks some of the depth that can be found in the most hardcore strategy games, but I do not feel this is a flaw. One of the greatest games ever devised, Chess, has only 6 unique pieces, and in its standard style of play, only allows for 1v1 competition. There is a delightfully simple elegance to the units and technologies available in AoWIII (which offer many more choices than Chess). Taken from a purely turn-based strategy game perspective, they would seem shallow compared to the game's peers, but in the context of a deep turn-based tactical RPG (with heroes levelling from 1-30, earning skill points to allocate each level, and spells to research, and gear to equip) it is plenty complex enough.

My favorite thing about this game is how amazingly stable my multiplayer experience has been.  My first time launching online multiplayer, it checked my connectivity rating, and told me it was poor due to firewall settings. I clicked a link provided in-game, and in a totally crisp and not buggy fashion, minimized my client and sent me to the company's help page, wherein I was given the neccessary port to forward. I did so, had the game check again, and was good to go. A friend and I have long searched for a good co-operative tactical RPG experience. The best I have yet found was FFT: The Lion War for PSP. It's a shame that a hand-held game system has trumped PC for so long in this niche. XCOM lacks co-op campaign functionality, Eador is horribly buggy and unstable, and the others I've tried are all crumby. In AoWIII, I've found that harmonious combination of enjoyable gameplay and completely (and I mean 8 straight hours of addictive, no crashes or disconnections) stable multiplayer.

Watch some videos of this game and decide if it suits your interests, but as for my opinion, I can give this one an A+.

reviewText:
Age of Wonders III is utterly amazing.

My view may be skewed due to putting 100+ hours into the original, but for newcomers to the series I highly recommend this title. The game play is 4X (eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate) much like the Civilization or Heroes of Might and Magic series. The game is set in a high fantasy world ripe with monstrous creatures, dungeons and undead armies. When playing a map (either a scenario, the campaign, or a randomly generated map) you start with a leader unit who, in scenarios or random maps, you create yourself and usually a small army based on one of the five races that you can choose with a city or a city building unit to start your empire. Your leader can level up as they defeat enemies with your armies and gain points to put into unique abilities based on their class and their offensive and defensive statistics. These abilities will help bolster the armies that they lead and push you ever closer to victory. The infantry units you command also gain experience and levels up to four but their abilities and stats are predetermined. Also based on the previously mentioned class and the actions you take to solidify an alignment, either good or evil, are the spells that you research along the way which is reminiscent of technology from the Civ franchise.

Along your journey you will more than likely run across heroes that will offer to join you, these characters are much like your leader, they level up the same, they gain abilities based on their class, and they are meant to lead armies. The big difference being that if you lose one of these heroes they are gone, much like other units in your army. Your leader will respawn at your throne city, assuming it's still standing, after a few turns but their friends will not. This makes the battles intense and the losses devastating. The battles are turn based on a hex map based on whatever landscape you're occupying and these maps are gorgeous. They really give you a look at the landscapes that your troops are marching through.

The class system mentioned above is a change to the series that after experiencing I can say is welcome. There are very distinct ways that each class works from the technology based, steam punkesque Dreadnaught to the classic magic juggernaut that is the Sorcerer. The Theocrat leads through belief and divine retribution with their crusaders, leading holy wars against their heretical enemies while the Rogue leads through deception, riots, and stealth. The Archdruid taps into the power of nature, summoning animal companions and nature elementals to their side while the Warlord rampages their armies with limited use of magic, ruling through blood, and battle.

Overall the game is a very unique and very fun experience. The soundtrack is breathtakingly beautiful with a few songs being a throwback to the original. Clearly I don't write reviews for a living (I know. Too many commas." "Where's the sentence structure?") but I feel like if I were to Age of Wonders would get a 5/5
recommended: or 100/100. The only gripe I could make is the lack of a few races from the previous games but that's nothing that an expansion or two won't fix. That
hoursPlayed: and the fact that I can't buy the collectors edition of the game. But life goes on. I'll be spending hours of mine in the Age of Wonders."

reviewText:
Ya, this game is really solid. I should preface this my saying my favorite genre of all time is turn based strategy, and while I usually prefer more focused experiences like Final Fantasy Tactics or Fire Emblem, every so often I like to go for a grander 4X game. That said, as a long time strategy fan, this game hits almost every note right with me.

First off, while this game is great, it does have a few minor issues that I would like to address before betting to the good stuff. The pace of the game can get very slow, especially when running large maps with many opponents. This can be compounded by the fact that you cant auto manage your cities and my inherant distrust for auto-resolving battles. Additionally, The simultaneous turn system feels a bit funky, and will often cause you to be ambushed mid turn before you can move your armies. This of course is easily fixed by changing the turns to classic.

Aside from those issues, the game plays great. There is a tone of variety in units between various combinations of races and classes and tons of neutral units that you will fight in your travels. The customization of heroes is insane and will give any hardcore strategy fan something to sink their teeth into. Best off all though is the execution of strategy in battles. Units die very easily which causes you to apply proper strategy to keep your army alive. Additionally, the game averts the turtling problem of many games of the genre by allowing multiple armies to attack a single hex at a time. This creates huge epic battles that blow games like HoMM out of the water while averting the frustration that comes from having a vastly superior army but being unable to take a single well defended city. Finally, the AI feels smart and a worthy advisary to challenge your dominion.

Overall, this game outpaces most of its competition in its genre. It has more than enough depth for any strategy fan while still being accessable and easy to pick up. If you are a strategy fan, you owe it to yourself to try this game.

reviewText:
I remember playing Age of Wonders 1 and 2 so long ago.  I can't recall how many hours I dumped into those games, especially the second one.  It was the reinvention of Master of Magic, and I loved it.  You get the great world map combined with many fantastic races and tactical combat on separate maps.  I could not have been happier.  It was the fantasy version of Civilization in many respects.

When I saw AoW3, I got anxious.  Finally it released, and I got to play it.  It truly has everything to remind me of the previous versions I loved, and then some.  Random Maps, finally.  Relevant units, yay.

AoW3 has random maps.  This seems normal, but previously they did not.  So after a while, it becomes mundane with the same strategies and outcomes per scenario.  You can build cities!  Couldn't do that in the old days.  It was all preset and you took what was already there.  Units are relevant now.  In AoW2 the best strategy was to raze every single building and town you took (except your starting city), then destroy the neutral armies that appeared, and farm all the xp and items you could for your starting hero. He becomes nigh invincible, even to tier 3 units, and has absurd movement with flight, so he can just zoom around the map with a scorched earth strategy.  I have not tried to do this in AoW3, but I suspect it would be ineffective.

If you liked the previous games in the series, you will still like this one. I cannot say anything bad about it. It is in line with everything I expected it to have. It stays true to the series, and offers some new things. The only thing it doesn't have, is the number of races that the priors had.  No Dark Elves, no Undead, etc... DLC right?  Seems fine.

All that being said, I would go 8/10 if you like the genre or the old games.  Personally, it's a 7 for me, and that is just because although I want to enjoy the battles and fight them manually, they become something of a chore to me and I end up auto'ing most of them, even if its a huge super important fight.  I would not have the patience anymore for multiplayer if people do manual fights, yet the prospect of not having the option to manual fight seems to gut a large aspect of the game's draw for me.

So I recommend this game overall, but you mind get a little bored with it if you have leaned towards RTS style games since playing AoW2, and maybe that's not worth the cost of the game for you.  Even so, it's a fine product and I am happy to support it, even if I don't play it as much as I thought I would.  (so many good games these days)

reviewText:
Age of Wonders III is utterly amazing.

My view may be skewed due to putting 100+ hours into the original, but for newcomers to the series I highly recommend this title. The game play is 4X (eXplore, eXpand, eXploit, and eXterminate) much like the Civilization or Heroes of Might and Magic series. The game is set in a high fantasy world ripe with monstrous creatures, dungeons and undead armies. When playing a map (either a scenario, the campaign, or a randomly generated map) you start with a leader unit who, in scenarios or random maps, you create yourself and usually a small army based on one of the five races that you can choose with a city or a city building unit to start your empire. Your leader can level up as they defeat enemies with your armies and gain points to put into unique abilities based on their class and their offensive and defensive statistics. These abilities will help bolster the armies that they lead and push you ever closer to victory. The infantry units you command also gain experience and levels up to four but their abilities and stats are predetermined. Also based on the previously mentioned class and the actions you take to solidify an alignment, either good or evil, are the spells that you research along the way which is reminiscent of technology from the Civ franchise.

Along your journey you will more than likely run across heroes that will offer to join you, these characters are much like your leader, they level up the same, they gain abilities based on their class, and they are meant to lead armies. The big difference being that if you lose one of these heroes they are gone, much like other units in your army. Your leader will respawn at your throne city, assuming it's still standing, after a few turns but their friends will not. This makes the battles intense and the losses devastating. The battles are turn based on a hex map based on whatever landscape you're occupying and these maps are gorgeous. They really give you a look at the landscapes that your troops are marching through.

The class system mentioned above is a change to the series that after experiencing I can say is welcome. There are very distinct ways that each class works from the technology based, steam punkesque Dreadnaught to the classic magic juggernaut that is the Sorcerer. The Theocrat leads through belief and divine retribution with their crusaders, leading holy wars against their heretical enemies while the Rogue leads through deception, riots, and stealth. The Archdruid taps into the power of nature, summoning animal companions and nature elementals to their side while the Warlord rampages their armies with limited use of magic, ruling through blood, and battle.

Overall the game is a very unique and very fun experience. The soundtrack is breathtakingly beautiful with a few songs being a throwback to the original. Clearly I don't write reviews for a living (I know. Too many commas." "Where's the sentence structure?") but I feel like if I were to Age of Wonders would get a 5/5
recommended: or 100/100. The only gripe I could make is the lack of a few races from the previous games but that's nothing that an expansion or two won't fix. That
hoursPlayed: and the fact that I can't buy the collectors edition of the game. But life goes on. I'll be spending hours of mine in the Age of Wonders."

reviewText:
This is the real deal.

Epic, sprawling, colorful and as deep as you want it to be.

Age of Wonders - Shadow Magic was easily my favorite 4X game back in the day and I've never found a completely satisfying replacement for it. I've dabbled with a variety of contenders over the years but none quite hit the same mark. When Fallen Enchantress rolled out recently, I gave it a shot but found it a bit clunky and ugly as all get out. Warlock is another fine game but it's lack of customization (seriously, is there NO WAY to turn off the ridiculous, ever-spawning monsters?) and odd constraints on actual spell casting left me wanting. King's Bounty and HoMM are in the same family tree but farther removed and not particularly strategic in nature - certainly not epic games of empires and war.

The real draw on Age of Wonders is that, much like Civ V, you can play it as deeply as you like. Not interested in min-maxing out racial modifiers and terrain-based morale requirements on a unit-by-unit basis? That's fine... play against simple AI and forget about that stuff by playing joy-ride sandbox games. Alternatively, a player could spend hours fussing over the ways that all of the unit and kingdom modifiers compliment each other.

Diplomacy and non-warfare tech is MUCH simpler than that of Civ V but that deficiency is offset by the unique nature of the various races and classes available. Every class and magic sphere combo opens up a tech tree of spells and skills that allow some rather unique empires to emerge and the horizon is WIDE open for future expansions.

Players should be forewarned that even a medium-sized map can take many hours to work through but there's rarely a moment from beginning to end where the user simply hits the NEXT TURN button without making some kind of imperial decision.

Great stuff... terribly addictive but great.

reviewText:
Ya, this game is really solid. I should preface this my saying my favorite genre of all time is turn based strategy, and while I usually prefer more focused experiences like Final Fantasy Tactics or Fire Emblem, every so often I like to go for a grander 4X game. That said, as a long time strategy fan, this game hits almost every note right with me.

First off, while this game is great, it does have a few minor issues that I would like to address before betting to the good stuff. The pace of the game can get very slow, especially when running large maps with many opponents. This can be compounded by the fact that you cant auto manage your cities and my inherant distrust for auto-resolving battles. Additionally, The simultaneous turn system feels a bit funky, and will often cause you to be ambushed mid turn before you can move your armies. This of course is easily fixed by changing the turns to classic.

Aside from those issues, the game plays great. There is a tone of variety in units between various combinations of races and classes and tons of neutral units that you will fight in your travels. The customization of heroes is insane and will give any hardcore strategy fan something to sink their teeth into. Best off all though is the execution of strategy in battles. Units die very easily which causes you to apply proper strategy to keep your army alive. Additionally, the game averts the turtling problem of many games of the genre by allowing multiple armies to attack a single hex at a time. This creates huge epic battles that blow games like HoMM out of the water while averting the frustration that comes from having a vastly superior army but being unable to take a single well defended city. Finally, the AI feels smart and a worthy advisary to challenge your dominion.

Overall, this game outpaces most of its competition in its genre. It has more than enough depth for any strategy fan while still being accessable and easy to pick up. If you are a strategy fan, you owe it to yourself to try this game.

reviewText:
I remember playing Age of Wonders 1 and 2 so long ago.  I can't recall how many hours I dumped into those games, especially the second one.  It was the reinvention of Master of Magic, and I loved it.  You get the great world map combined with many fantastic races and tactical combat on separate maps.  I could not have been happier.  It was the fantasy version of Civilization in many respects.

When I saw AoW3, I got anxious.  Finally it released, and I got to play it.  It truly has everything to remind me of the previous versions I loved, and then some.  Random Maps, finally.  Relevant units, yay.

AoW3 has random maps.  This seems normal, but previously they did not.  So after a while, it becomes mundane with the same strategies and outcomes per scenario.  You can build cities!  Couldn't do that in the old days.  It was all preset and you took what was already there.  Units are relevant now.  In AoW2 the best strategy was to raze every single building and town you took (except your starting city), then destroy the neutral armies that appeared, and farm all the xp and items you could for your starting hero. He becomes nigh invincible, even to tier 3 units, and has absurd movement with flight, so he can just zoom around the map with a scorched earth strategy.  I have not tried to do this in AoW3, but I suspect it would be ineffective.

If you liked the previous games in the series, you will still like this one. I cannot say anything bad about it. It is in line with everything I expected it to have. It stays true to the series, and offers some new things. The only thing it doesn't have, is the number of races that the priors had.  No Dark Elves, no Undead, etc... DLC right?  Seems fine.

All that being said, I would go 8/10 if you like the genre or the old games.  Personally, it's a 7 for me, and that is just because although I want to enjoy the battles and fight them manually, they become something of a chore to me and I end up auto'ing most of them, even if its a huge super important fight.  I would not have the patience anymore for multiplayer if people do manual fights, yet the prospect of not having the option to manual fight seems to gut a large aspect of the game's draw for me.

So I recommend this game overall, but you mind get a little bored with it if you have leaned towards RTS style games since playing AoW2, and maybe that's not worth the cost of the game for you.  Even so, it's a fine product and I am happy to support it, even if I don't play it as much as I thought I would.  (so many good games these days)

Great game. I have lots of experienced with turn based strategies of all flavors, and this one holds up.

Since a lot of great reviews are out there, I'll just reaffirm the ones that state this game focuses more on action and less on managemet. The city management system is fairly shallow, but deep enough to keep it interesting. The combat however is superb and the level of detail for both character design and animation is just astounding. I do love the AoW3 campaign though, great concept incorporating single player RPG's into a turn based strategy sim, I dig it.

reviewText:
Age of Wonders 3 is an excellent 4X strategy game that is hard to learn, but rewarding to play. Compared to other games of it's type, AW3 offers a much deeper combat system and a wide veriety of strategies and compositions. If you have a lot of spare time, love/are interested in grand strategy titles, and/or like the themes of traitional medieval fantacy, I would highly reccomend this game.

Pros:
- Excellent turn based combat system that favors strategy over raw stats
- Races and Classes feel unique to play and favor sometimes wildly different strategies. Lots of options.
- Optional, yet deep, character customization.
- The world is fun to explore - and very rewarding. There's always something productive to do.
- DLC adds game changing elements that are worth investing in if you enjoy the base game
- You CAN add more races into your empire, leading to even more wild compositions
- Campaign mode offers a more flavorful world, and each unit has a flavorful story tied to it. World is more immersive.

Cons:
- Some race/class combinations are much weaker than others.
- Tutorial is very bad - game is hard to learn, and harder to understand.
- Campaign maps favor rush tatics over late game strategies. Also, unfathomable gaps exist between difficult levels (easy being almost braindead, and normal being infuriatingly hard.)
- Barebones diplomacy system.
- The base game its all about domination. Mre options are availible with DLC, but I would advise rushing to buy something if you don't know whether or not its right for you.
- Cities lack much thematic diversity, are like the diplomatic system are more barebone.
- No just one more turn" button.

I give Age of Wonders 3 a 9/10. Its pros outweigh almost all of its cons
date: and with a more in depth diplomacy system and optional post victory gameplay
recommended: it could easily have earned a 10/10 from me."

reviewText:
This game is a true strategy game, a wonder that combines hex-based strategy with city managment and the growing of heros. The game has a good campaign, although the multiplayer and the skirmishes are better. It also features leader creation, so you can build multiple leaders from any of the playable races in the game.

The game also features a class system, which with regards to your heros, means they get skills based on their class. With regards to your leader, they also get skills, but this also determines what types of units you can build.

The game has some seriousness to it, be it the evil necromancers, wanting to bring the world to the apocolypse, with the help of undead dragons, reapers, and fallen angels, to the holy theocrats who want to bring peace to the world. The game also has some sillyness to it, tameing fairies and dire penguins, and other ridiculous creatures.

I would truly recommend this game, it is sure to bring you hours of fun, both by yourself and with your friends!

reviewText: Where do I start...let me first say this game has definitely bkown away my expectations and what a turn based game should be. I have been a follower of the Heroes of Might and Magic series since the beginning. Developers at the Heroes camp need to take a page out of this book and use it. The biggest thing I like about this game is the option to ally with either a human or AI opponent and then play on whatever map you like. There are no restrictions to this at all. reviewText:
So, I played the original Age of Wonders and Age of Wonders 2, as well Shadow Magic, which was a stand alone expansion for Age of Wonders 2, so I was naturally quite interested when I heard Age of Wonders 3 was coming out. Somehow I'd managed to miss that it was even in production until about a month before it was released. Nevertheless, after starting to read about the game, I was a bit wary as some of the changes did not seem positive. However, being a fan of the series as a whole, I had to at least give it a try.

So... is Age of Wonders 3 a good game? Well, your answer to that would no doubt be influenced by whether you have played any of the previous games in the series. Having played them, I would say, yes this is a good game but, relative to its time, the game is perhaps not as good as the previous titles in the series.

For those of you who don't know, Age of Wonder is a fantasy turn-based strategy, with large amounts of magic, heroes and different races. In Age of Wonders, your leader was a hero and he or she travelled about with your army, gaining levels, exploring ancient ruins and so on. For Age of Wonders 2, your hero became a wizard who spent all his or her time sitting in their tower casting spells. With Age of Wonders 3, the system has gone back to that of the original Age of Wonders (i.e. your leader being an active participant in the world) so in this sense it has been an improvement from 2.

Also the graphics are quite good and has a certain fantastical feel about it, I don't know if it's the shades and the hues, but it does feel quite vivid and rich. Also when you zoom out in the world screen, the view changes to a stylised map, as drawn on parchment, think the map of Middle-Earth, which I think looks really good.

One of the biggest issues I had with the game prior to getting it was the massive cut the number of races, now there are only six: Goblins, Orcs, Dwarfs, Humans, Draconians and High Elves. This basicaly means many of the races from AoW2 are gone: Dark Elves/Wood Elves (although there is an in-game reason why they no longer exist, basically they kissed and made up and reformed as the High Elves), Frostlings, Halflings, etc. And yes, I would say the lack of races is quite noticable. I've played just 2 levels in one of the campaigns and during that time I've captured and held cities belonging to every single race in the game except for the dwarves. Considering I've only just started the third level, it seems odd that I've nearly played as every single race already. So, yes, I suppose there is certainly much less variation than there was.

One of the ways that is suposed to reduce the imact of this lack of variation is by having small settlements belonging to 'minor races' which you can capture and then train units from other races. For example, I captured a fey settlement and was thus able to train various fey units, and construct buildings to improve them, as well as unlock different units that could be trained. I was actually quite surprised how much depth there was in this. You seem to be able to train 5-6 different units, and a fair number of buildings. I was expecting 2-3 different units at most. Nevertheless, they're still less in depth than a city from one of the main six races, and of course you can't build them.

Combat is pretty much the same as the previous Age of Wonders games, and the additions with the new 3D engine are nice, for example having units consist of multiple men, the numbers of which go down as the unit gets injured.

The system regarding magic spheres is a bit different to the previous titles in the series. Essentially, each hero has three different specialisations and if you're creating your own hero you can pick three from a list. These consist of 6 different areas of magic (water, fire, air, earth, creation and destruction), expander and explorer. Because of this, you can select a minimum of one area of magic and a maximum of three. This influences what you can research and what can subsequently use. When you do create a hero, you get quite a lot of customisation options in terms of apperance. You also have a range of different classes you can select for your hero: dreadnaught, druid, sorcerer, etc. Each of these gives you at least one unique building (which may be upgradable) and unique unit, however apart from that there seems to be little differences between the different classes. Being one class or the other doesn't influence the specialisations you can select for example, and these specialisations seem to have a much greater influence over your character than what class they are.

The music in Age of Wonders 3 isn't anything special in my opinion. It's alright, but it's not amazingly noticable and there haven't been any songs I've particularly sat up and particularly enjoyed, compared to Age of Wonders 1 where there were a few songs I particularly liked, such as the March of the Halflings.

People have reported having FPS issues, and I get them myself, but for me personally it's mostly fine, just a bit slow but certainly playable. The developers are aware of this and are currently working on fixing it.

Also, I have to comend the voice acting in Age of Wonders 3. I've only played one campaign but the voice acting for the main character from whose point of view the stoy is told is actually very good.

I admit this review hasn't been the most well structured, but to conclude, I think Age of Wonders 3 is a good game, perhaps a very good game but not an excellent game, and not as good as the previous games in the series and it does have some flaws. It is certainly is screaming out for some kind of expansion/DLC just to add a bit more variation and depth. Even with the minor races you can find and recruit, six major races does seem a bit few but I certainly don't regret buying it.

reviewText:
This is a game that makes me look up and look at the clock and realise that 7 hours of my life has just passed by and it is suddenly light outside and oh god I need to sleep before I have to go to work and oh alright then, just one more turn and then I will defintiely go to bed...

Stylistically it is a cartoony version of games such as Heroes of Might and Magic where you control a Hero and their own faction of fantasy scamps out to do valiant battle against other assorted fantasy tropes and critters. But under the cheery colourful exterior there is a very good game that, although with limitations, scratches almost all of my fantasy strategy empire building rpg itches. The RPG style Hero levelling and item system is well executed. The empire building is decent. The battles can be pretty fun and sometimes even quite challenging. The diplomacy is about as good as any other 4X game I've played and not as awful as some of them although I have yet to try to win diplomatically and so I am not sure if that is even an option. I have not played AoW 1 or 2 so I have no idea if they are better or worse than this installment but as I said, I think this one is addictive good fun.

Now I feel that there is room for improvement. The late game is a bit of a boring grind; as your cities expand they all turn out a bit samey. The AI is not terrible and I have been beaten by it a few times but I wish they would actually do a bit of empire building on its own: they never build roads or forts for example. Perhaps it is better against human players but as I have no friends I have yet to experience that aspect of the game.

All in all, if you like your 4X's but feel that CIV V doesn't feature enough ogres, imps or kobold minions then you should defintiely give this title a go. Also the two first expansions are good additions that in my opinion adds a lot of essential content to the vanilla game so maybe wait for a sale to get the bundle. Just a tip.

reviewText:
If you like games like the Civilization series, or the Heroes of Might & Magic series, and are hankering for a new high-fantasy strategy game to play, do yourself a favor and check this game out! This was my first experience with the Age of Wonders series, I was looking through the Steam store for something new, saw it and decided to give it a go. I didn't expect much given the usual quality of today's games but man was I surprised!

Here is my pros and cons list based on my experience playing the base game, I haven't bought the expansion packs yet but I definitely plan to.

Pros :
- Challenging gameplay that requires you to think ahead, as well as think quickly on your feet.
- Good AI.
- Wide variety of fantasy creatures to go up against, or enlist in your own army.
- Active modding community on the Steam Workshop.
- Beautiful visuals.
- Large arsenal of spells, abilities, upgrades and equipment that make each Leader feel unique.
- Nice soundtrack that does a good job of adding to the immersion.
- A character creation system that offers a good deal of customization for this sort of game.
- Boatloads of replayability.

Cons :
- Some units and abilities seem rather imbalanced, but nothing gamebreaking.
- Challenge can sometimes ramp up drastically.
- Cities could use a bit more diversity, while it is possible to have a city that is specialized in performing a certain role, I haven't yet found that to be necessary and as a result all my cities have pretty much had the same buildings. I think this could have been improved by making a tech-tree for cities so you would have to decide what you want that city's main purpose to be. But, since the game is focused more on armies and combat rather than city building, this isn't a huge deal.
- Very few visual changes on your Leaders and Heroes in regard to their equipment, the only items that change your appearance are your mount and your weapon. This is more of a personal desire and not so much something the game did wrong,  it IS a strategy game after all and would require alot of effort to implement. but still, I was a bit let down when I looted a very awesome looking helmet and chest piece only to find that it didn't affect my appearance. Once again, not a huge deal though.

reviewText:
AOW 3 is a very addictive turn-based X4 game set in a fantasy world, which  has procedurally generated maps for skirmishes and a few campaigns and scenarios. Each match you'll take command of a faction, defined by your leader's race and class. There are 9 different races and 8 different classes, each very unique, and any combination of them can be formed. Furthermore, you can choose up to 3 specializations for your leader, allowing for a ridiculous amount of possibilities. The game focuses a lot on turn-based combat and exploration, akin to HOMM, but improves upon it on several fronts.

Pros:

- HUGE number of unique units, heroes and spells
- Great fantasy setting
- Diplomacy is functional but unnecessary
- Combat and game mechanics are easy to grasp, but deep and complex. All this complexity is hidden in a user-friendly interface, so there is no need to panic.
- Many treasures to unlock through exploration and combat
- Resource structures on your city domain often adds unique, important bonuses to economy or military.
- RPG elements such as leader customization and progression through combat experience. Each unit also levels up and may gain new abilities.
- Factions are very balanced overall
- AI is way above average. Not perfect, but very good compared to other games
- The world is beautiful and detailed. Graphics are very good.

Cons:

- Multiplayer isn't so good. It lacks dynamism.
- Higher difficulty AI receives resource bonuses rather than greater skill.
- Some elements of the interface could be improved, such as managing your active spells.
- Procedural map generators often create odd maps, with several different biomes not spread out in a logical way. You have snow biomes close to tropical ones followed by temperate regions, for instance.
- Map editor is pretty complicated to use.

9/10

reviewText:
Great game for those who like turn based combat with a high fantasy setting.
There are many races (human, goblin, elves, etc.) that you can combine with different classes (rouge, socerer, dreadnought, etc.) and then with a specialization (fire, water, creation, destruction, etc.).
Each combination requires different strategies and plays very unique.
I personally enjoyed playing as an air specialized frostling nacromancer (DLC), where I convert the whole land into ice field, turn enemies into ghouls, and march the land with an army of undead.  There more death the more powerful a nacromancer.

The presentation of the game is very good and very polished.
The single player campaign is a bit lacking, as the random map mode is where this game shines (similar to Civilization 5).
Unlike Civilization series, Age of Wonders 3 focus on combat in a tatical map.
The tatical maps are very detailed and reflect the tiles of the strategic map that the units were on.
Units have many abilities.  Player can also have hero units with RPG upgrade elements.

There are only very basic diplomacy and empire building, but the battle is where this game produce the most enjoyment.
The DLCs are also very wonderful and included new races to play that really expanded the experience of this game.

If you like high fantasy settings (dragons, trolls, goblins, dwarves, elves, kights, magic and so on), then do give this game a try.

reviewText:
Although this game will likely become 2014's hidden gem, Age of Wonders 3 is a pretty good take on turn-based strategy games.

Regarding empire management, I've noticed that some have commented that when compared to games like Civilization, the empire management is more or less streamlined, and to me, building up my empire wasn't too difficult.

I imagine that this is done to give a larger focus on the combat system, where the focus is no longer on the world map, but rather on a smaller tactical map where players command the party or parties they've formed and pit them against each other (either in open terrain or a siege depending on where the defending party is standing on at the time of the attack). I found it enjoyable that the Age of Wonders series brings you to this hex-based tactical view, though the previous games were heavily reliant on a random number generator, which can sometimes have your entire starting party be killed by 2 starting units.

Age of Wonders 3 throws the random number generator out the window, meaning that defense/resistance actually reduces physical and magic damage. Additionally, line of sight and range penalties act as damage reductions, rather than giving ranged weapons a chance of missing entirely. Personally, i find that it's really nice that combat is no longer reliant on an in-game RNG, although I'm probably saying that because I've lost an entire party to 2 goblin militia units in Age of Wonders: Shadow Magic.

And finally, the initial set-up (I probably should've started from here). Compared to Age of Wonders 1, it's somewhat simplified in the sense that you can't allocate your starting stats (I think this was done to prevent abuse, since you can pretty much start with 2-3 types of elemental melee damage), although this is more or less offset by the ability to choose your leader's race and class, which I felt is pretty fun to play around with.

Overall, I find that Age of Wonders 3 is an awesome game for those who enjoy fantasy turn-based strategy games.

reviewText:
How a sequel should be done. It preserves all the things that made AoW a good series so far, but it improves all the things that weren't great about previous games. The quests idea was just an annoyance in AoW2, and in this game it works far better. They are not compulsory but if you do them they improve your relations with one of the races on the map, and if they end up liking you, they will give you tributes of money or units from time to time. So quests are now worthwhile and useful. The also improved the way research works and the progression of your characters. You can no longer slide a bar to select how much goes towards research or mana, because that was exploitable. Now your mana and research are fixed and you cast spells or research stuff over a set number of turns, and you can improve this by having buildings produce extra mana or research on one of their turns. The result is that hero upgrades and research comes more gradually and steadily over the whole game, without big spikes that make things too easy.

Also experience is split amongst a whole army fighting, and the amount of points to increase certain things on a hero will increase if you keep focusing on it. So you will have enough points to make a well rounded hero, but you wont have enough to add +50 to the few things that could make them godlike in previous games.

There are other improvements too, but basically it feels like AoW 2 did but with everything refined to work properly as it should, and not like hastily added features. It also has great music and the graphics are improved too. Overall, it is a true sequel to AoW 1 and 2. It gives stuff we missed from AoW1 like a wider range of skills for heroes and more interesting upgrades for them, and it has better underground play too like AoW1. But it also has features from AoW2 like quests and better world magic, it just does them better now.

Great game.

reviewText:
I'll start with the good news: this really is a worthy successor to the earlier parts of the series, and I definitely recommend it to any fan of turn-based strategy games.

That said, it does have a few flaws that need to be addressed.

- The alignment system...doesn't work. There's no penalty to playing the good guy, so you'll pretty much always gravitate towards a Pure Good alignment unless you make a deliberate effort to be evil, and since there are distinct penalties for playing the bad guy you end up gimping yourself in the progress.

- While the move to 3D certainly improved animation quality, some models (especially flying creatures) are just plain hideous to look at. I have absolutely no idea what they were trying to achieve with the gryphon, for example :P.

- The loss of many staple races is a bit of a pain, although the new class-based units do help to put some of the variety back in.

- Speaking of that, some things about the race/class system aren't exactly explained very well. Class units of different races do have noticably different stats, which is something you're left to find out for yourself (hint: elves, as usual, do very well with any kind of ranged attack).

- And finally, there's a certain amount of interface clunkiness going on. No major showstoppers, but a lot of minor things that'll get a little annoying over time.



So...what makes this worth buying despite the flaws I just outlined?

- A solid TBS experience with RPG elements.
- A fun, if somewhat clich'd setting.
- Amazing music.
- Elven musketeers.
- The classes really do offer vastly different playstyles. If you try the approach you won with as a Warlord with an Archdruid character, you will probably fail pretty hard.
- Character traits make a huge difference in playstyle as well.
- Goblin angels.
- Random map generator with good fine-tuning options provides long-term replayability.
- The series' trademark sense of humor is still around and going strong, particularly in the unit descriptions.



All in all, a very solid game despite some flaws, and probably the best of its kind out right now.

reviewText:
Of all 4X games, this is my favourite. I have been a fan of the AoW series since 1999, and believe that this game borrows nicely from its predecessors but also introduces fantastic new features and content.

The game is very detailed, with huge amounts of units, spells and abilities (many more than the previous games). The strategic map is beautiful, has many varied features and is always different thanks to the excellent random map generator.

The tactical map is much improved, and is similarly pleasing to the eye. Units have the ability to flank, to gang up on stronger units and tie them up; these features improve this mode greatly.

The addition of classes (e.g. rogue, Sorcerer) to the existing race based system is something that some people like and others do not. The negatives say that the emphasis is clearly on class and that choice of race doesnt matter. However, the classes arguably make up for this as they bring many different units and spells. Also, Triumph have been adding changes that improve racial diversity.

One thing to mention here is that Triumph seem to want to listen to the community. Many gripes about the game when it came out have been addressed. As a company they seem to be passionate about what they do, giving the fans what they want and not being too mercenary in their approach to DLC etc.

If I had to say what was wrong with the game, there would be two minor gripes. Firstly, while sieges look visually impressive, they are all virtually the same. Every time you must attack the same shape of city wall and seeing as sieges are so common a battleground, sometimes the game can feel (slightly) monotonous for this reason.

Secondly, while multiplayer (player versus player) is exciting, it can be awkward to organise games and can be very time consuming. Basic things like an in lobby chat have been left out. The community often uses house rules like 'no attacking in the first 15 seconds of the turn' and 'do not purposefully attack my stacks of units to take my adjacent stacks out of the fight'. These make perfect sense and are used for nearly all games, but it relies on player honesty. I hope that triumph addresses this in a future patch. The signs are positive as they have implemented a number of positive changes to multiplayer already. I must say that multiplayer is a lot of fun and would recommend it for those that have patience.

To sum this game up; it has a rich fantasy setting, looks fantastic, has awesome empire building features and tactical battles, and it is genuinely improving with the additions of new patches and DLC.

reviewText:
I should have reviewed this game long ago.

Age of Wonders 3 is an amazing fantasy turn based 4x with rpg elements, and a fantastic array of choices, customization and tactical options.

I would sit here and list them all, but I will condense it to afew points.

Have you ever played a 4x and wanted to actually be on the battlefield? To have a presence? In AoW 3 you can, as a sovereign you can fight on the battlefield (and revive if killed too) gain levels, and lead a glorious army, or have your heroes do it for you (or fight alongside them)

Have you ever wanted to be able to both play a nice, friendly, intercultural hero of the people? Or be the devious evil genociding brutal wizard lord? Both are viable strategies, and have their strengths and weaknesses especially with all the new updates related to alignment, and racial approval/happiness.

Do you itch for a game with a varied class selection of rather different yet equal classes? From the ttrategy, tactics, and military might of the warlord, and the sneaky cunning of the rogue to the vast arcane power of the wizard and religious/moral power of the theocrat (and several other classes, alongside the necromancer soon to be released) you have access to a vast array of balanced, interesting, and flavorful classes.

Balance is both already good, and improving all the time as the developers follow the approach of Adding content, and adding power rather than simply cutting content, and nerfing to improve balance, orks not strong enough? We aughta give them a new unit option, and a damage buff, not nerf everyone else. It's wonderful, and so very productive.

All in all do I feel like I got my money's worth with this purchase? I very much do, I was worried after years without a new game that this game would fail to live up to the nostalgia of AoW Shadow Magic, instead it actually improved upon it's predecessor, and captured my attentions all over again. I'd rate this game 9.5 out of 10, the highest rating of any game in my 450+ title library. If you're a fan of 4x, rpgs, or fantasy and are even remotely considering this title I give you my absolute recommendation.

Well what are you waiting for? Buy it! (if you must wait for a sale then fine, but at any price under 30 bucks this game is just too good to pass up you owe it to yourself)

reviewText:
Age of Wonders III has come a long way since it's release. I'll be honest, I probably never had higher expectations on a computer game since I endorsed both Age of Wonders II and Shadow Magic and played them throughout an entire decade ... so after my first few games with AoW 3 I got a little disappointed. The game felt too fast, the starting race was much less significant than in the previous games and so felt the pick of the magical specilazations. Also I wasn't happy with some combat simplifications like flying units that suddenly had to land, the removal of friendly fire in ranged attacks etc ...

Lucky for me (and for most other AoW 3 players I'd say) Triumph Studios wouldn't be Triumph Studios if they didn't listen to their community. With each patch more and more issues the playerbase initially had with the game got fixed with the result that now with it's free 1.5 patch (and the two expansions, if you bought them) the game is very convenient to play and feels very complete content-wise - just right for another ten years of gaming time ;)

What you shouldn't expect AoW 3 to be is a civilization clone in a fantasy setting. While in civilization the main focus always has been on the empire building and management (let's say the strategical component) with Age of Wonders it's pretty much the opposite. The tactical combat is complex, demanding and offers tons of possibilities and while I personally wouldn't have sacrificed some of the mentioned combat characteristics of the previous games, Age of Wonders 3 can compensate their absence by introducing the guard mode and flanking system.

reviewText:
In the era, when the huge companies are either streamlining the previous games with usualll tendency to loose anything from the atmosphere of the old best sellers (yes, Heroes, im talking about You...) or even trying to squeeze Your wallets with so called HD feature stripped reedition (Yes, again Heroes of Might and Magic) asking You to pay a full price there it is - something out of the today standards.

Despite always being somewhere in the shadow of HoMM series, AoW series is nowhere behind the legacy of turn based fantasy strategic games. And even if it obviously was overshadowed by allmighty Heroes III (which is probably the best game ever for majority of players reading this review - me included) at the times where Age of Wonders 2 was published (even, despite my opinion it was pretty much equally good in some terms), its no longer a case.

Heroes series lost all of it glory throughour the years. Age of Wonders, resurrected not so far ago. And in a contrast of really average attempts to recover HoMM franchise, Triumph Studios made it done. This is the game every AoW fan was waiting for, and this is the game all the turn based fantasy strategic games fans should head into now. There is absolutely no other game in the genre with so much detail, fun and polish.

Of course, the game has some issues (like multiplayer connection which for no reason tries to establish p2p connection which is kind off archaic method) but developers are constantly updating the game based on our feedback.

So if You really enjoyed playin HoMM 3 twenty years ago, and You would love to feel something similar today - go grab it. You'll love it.

As a long time fan of the series I wanted to like this game I really did, but it is simply one large dissapointment. If you take the last game in the series and remove things you get the new game. reviewText:
Cons:
- Too few races to cover all types of gameplay in contrast to previous games in the series
- As such many spells/abilities fit/counter races that don't exist yet/not present on release
- The need to add those races through DLCs

(the following issues are common in AoW series and, unfortunately, are present here as well)
- Weak late game AI
- Campaigns are mediocre
- Tier 4 units still leave lower tier units biting the dust as such making them obsolete
- Many spells are seldom useful

Pros:
- The lack of races is compensated by the new leader class system that adds a lot of new units and spells adding truly a lot to the gameplay variety
- RPG-style heroes
- The races are more varied compared to previous games in the series with more apparent difference in strength/weaknesses of separate units
- Tier 4 units are tough to come by (have to capture settlements enabling them, although a few leader classes allow such units as well) and aren't as easy to spam as top racial units in AoW2/SM
- Too powerful spells are nerfed/made more dangerous to the caster compared to AoWSM (like Hellfire) so no more 1 spell deciding the outcome of the whole battle
- Vastly improved random map generator
- Pretty graphics (as usual in AoW)
- Nice soundtrack by Michiel van den Bos
- ONE MORE TURN

Overall despite all the issues, new or common to AoW, this is a worthy successor to the series and even a base game offers a lot at its pricepoint compared to a more expensive competition.
And much like previous games in the series AoW3 plays a lot differently than its prequels, offering fresher gameplay instead of just being a reskin and thus making it stand out, while AoW1 and AoW2/SM still remain just as playable today.

reviewText:
Age of Wonders III is about empire building like Civilization and Age of Empires games, turn-based tactical battles like Heroes of Might and Magic and King's Bounty, and role playing.

What I find really attractive in AoW 3 is the importance of combat experience: in addition to heroes, other units gain experience points as well by interacting in the battle. This allows leveling up for the units to improve their efficiency in combat, which makes you think twice before sacrificing a unit in a battle to gain a momentary advantage over AI. Due to leveling up, it's possible to even beat down a dragon in a combat by using a single assassin.

While empire building is not its main focus, it is an essential part of AoW 3 due to unit upkeep costs and expensive buildings and units. The game has adopted several elements from Civilization games, such as happiness, which has significant effects on economy and science. Diplomacy is also an important factor: I've only played two random map games, but they both ended in my win through allied victory.

Despite AoW 3 contains only six different races, there is much replay value due to leader class system. There are six different leader classes, which determine which special units your cities may produce. So far, I've only played Rogue and Dreadnought, but they felt balanced relative to each other.

The biggest concern for me are the lame effects of artifacts in the game. Even the artifacts hyped as 'legendary' seldom have impressive effects on the hero or the units in hero's army.

In conclusion, this game is mainly focused on spectacular tactical battles and role playing in a fantasy world, and secondarily on empire building. Well worth the 22.49 I paid.

How do you know when a game has surpassed its predeccessors? I believe it's at the moment that you start to think of the current version, rather than its predecessors, as definitive of the series.

With update 1.5 (still beta as it is) AOWIII has now reached that stage.

Let me give you an example.

I am a sorceror-dwarf playing on the far right of the map, and peaceful with my immediate neighbors.  Voraditius the Theocrat is on the far left and quickly disposes of his Orc-Warlord neighbour, then declares war on me. This is at about turn 60, so both sides have top-level units available. We both decide - that's the correct expression, I'm sure -  to conduct reconnaissances in force on each other's territory.  I drop a couple of Horrors into my defending stack and see his raiders off handily. It's what happens at the other end of the map that is so brilliant. Bear in mind that I'm adding a Horror to my invaders each other turn, or a erpent each turn If I run low on troops, plus various gold conventional troops totalling two stacks. at the outset.

Voraditius plays like Napoleon.

Attack his towns? Those anaemic looking defennders turn out to be backed up with the power of Shrine of Animation, which brings back my own troops as undead on his team. Ignominious defeat.

Probe for weaknesses? He concentrates his stacks with diabolical ingenuity and sends me packing with heavy losses.

I send another hero with a stack of Naga units. Same thing happens - Immobilisation is killing me. Eventually I have to rethink and send the right units and heroes to tackle the Napocrat and his omnipotent Shrines of Smiting.

It helps to sac units to distract his armies to positions where they can be picked off. I'm also sending futher troops (giants and siege equipment to tackle the walls, which I should probably have done at the start). I catch Voraditius the little Corsican in the open and send him to the void for a couple of turns, during which I can run riot, Black Prince style. At last we face other in a huge Waterloo-type battle where I have only 3 units left at the end. Voraditius capitulates. Pure Turing - no way of telling he was 'just' an AI opponent.

Only one issue; Another opponent kept declaring war on Voraditius even after he was defeated. Entirely understandable, but a little strange.

All this in simple a random scenario. Ten thumbs up - a new classic is born.
