reviewText: This game is very entertaining. I am mainly writing to respond to criticisms that the game lacks depth, which initially made me hestitant about the game. The sale price of 19.99 USD tipped the scales in favor of the game (I was also considering Solar Empire and Endless Space). I'm glad the sale was going on because so far this is a great purchase. For a pure 4x game, I could see a lack of depth. However, this game is a hybrid between a 4x and RPG. I find RPGs too shallow to hold my interest, but the RPG elements here add a facet to this game that I haven't seen in other 4x games. The fact that it's unique makes it interesting. True...the research tree is anemic, but I have a lot of fun learning the spells, which have a fresh and dynamic affect on every aspect of the gaming experience. But to me, the RPG-style battle engine is what takes this to the next level. It is somewhat complex and very engaging, and mixed with more traditional 4x aspects, AOW III provides a nice experience that has kept my interest through that crucial first 24 hours. It also helps that the gameplay is smooth and intuitive, and the graphics are beautiful. So far, this is my favorite purchase since Civ V. One note is that I did have a crash. However, this was after a 14-hour session.

reviewText:
I'm having a lot of fun with the game. It's one of those games that I got on sale but wouldn't have been upset if I paid full price.

At first I was a little disappointed, there only seemed to be two campaigns. The high elves and the dwarfs, but you pick up other companions who help you and than you play their part of the campaign.   Example, first you play as a rouge Elf, but you quickly pick up a Draccon. When that part of the campaign is over it starts off as the Draccon in charge, but your high elf is still one of the leaders.

Again I was little disappointed because the first part of the campaign was long, so I figured it was over. Nope! As I said another character steps in and they become the primary champ.

I'm 15 hours plus on the second part of the campaign, I had to restart a few times. It can be a little trial by era but once you learn (and this goes into the actually strategy of the game) you know the most expensive units may not be your best.

Your main champs level up, but only to a certain point per campaign as well as your units but they don't carry over to the next stage of the campaign.  Basically your starting from scratch just your Champs keep their ability points and gear you might find.

The AI isn't stupid, the game has a auto match feature for annoying little battles which I didn't think I would use. Even if your likely to defeated you can pull off a win if your in a castle and play smart, and use your units properly and cast the right spells. However there are times where you have no chance in hell of winning and your goal becomes to hurt and kill your attacker as much as possible, so you can send in another force and destroy them but having a major champ in the game can cause one big bust which means you have to restart or have a back up save.

The storyline is rather weak but I'm okay with that, you get a big explanation in the start but your goal isn't always clear. Best advice is build up your money and mana before going to war if no one is attacking you. A lot of the towns you start will be useless besides for their money and mana benefits.  Basically you want to create a choke point and produce your troops from only a few locations. With that said some units take up money and mana every round so plan ahead. You can go through 20 turns with nothing really happening if you don't want it to.

The Good:

reviewText:
Age of Wonders III is about empire building like Civilization and Age of Empires games, turn-based tactical battles like Heroes of Might and Magic and King's Bounty, and role playing.

What I find really attractive in AoW 3 is the importance of combat experience: in addition to heroes, other units gain experience points as well by interacting in the battle. This allows leveling up for the units to improve their efficiency in combat, which makes you think twice before sacrificing a unit in a battle to gain a momentary advantage over AI. Due to leveling up, it's possible to even beat down a dragon in a combat by using a single assassin.

While empire building is not its main focus, it is an essential part of AoW 3 due to unit upkeep costs and expensive buildings and units. The game has adopted several elements from Civilization games, such as happiness, which has significant effects on economy and science. Diplomacy is also an important factor: I've only played two random map games, but they both ended in my win through allied victory.

Despite AoW 3 contains only six different races, there is much replay value due to leader class system. There are six different leader classes, which determine which special units your cities may produce. So far, I've only played Rogue and Dreadnought, but they felt balanced relative to each other.

The biggest concern for me are the lame effects of artifacts in the game. Even the artifacts hyped as 'legendary' seldom have impressive effects on the hero or the units in hero's army.

In conclusion, this game is mainly focused on spectacular tactical battles and role playing in a fantasy world, and secondarily on empire building. Well worth the 22.49 I paid.

reviewText:
Civilization V meets Heroes of Might & Magic is how I would best describe this game.

The fantasy setting is hardly original but the game is gorgeously presented with an easy to use interface, lovely artwork and graphics (anti-aliasing is poor but you can force MSAA+SGSSAA via the driver if you have an NVIDIA graphics card) and a wonderfully atmospheric musical score that fits the game perfectly.

Thankfully, the game plays as good as it looks and sounds as well. I've found the game to be very immersive and entertaining, even relaxing as you can focus on building up your cities and forces and set the combat to Auto and just watch it unfold in real-time if you wish.

If you are a fan of this genre then this is a must-have in my opinion.

reviewText:
I whole-heartedly recommend Age of Wonders III to everyone who likes turn-based strategy.

It is a sequel to a game series that manages to hit that sweet spot every sequel wants to hit: To introduce enough new content and mechanics to be its own game, while managing to keep up the feeling of the original.

And it's just as addicting, too. You can play either via network (Internet or local), or the good old hot-seat mode. Just remember to ask your friends to bring a sleeping bag when starting a hotseat game on a huge map, because you might be busy for a week.

There are campaigns of different difficulty for a smooth learning curve, and they also provide you with an interesting story in which your choices matter (Not every choice, of course, but there are points where you can choose which direction the story takes).

The game is a good way to start with TBS games, not only because of the good tutorial provided by the first campaign map, but also the helpful UI. At the beginning of your turn, it shows you everything that happened as messages on the side of the screen, and provides you with a button that tells you which issue to deal with next. That might be considered a bit mothering, but it certainly helps to prevent you from forgetting to order a new building in one of your cities, which can easily slip your mind in an empire of twenty metropolises.

There are a few things that I have issue with, most notably some balance choices, but the devs are active, and listening to the community, so that will only improve over time. As long as there's people willing to buy the game, they will continue to deliver, and not only small balance patches, but also large dlcs with new factions, classes and campaigns.

reviewText:
I am a huge fan of turn-based strategy games and turn-based RPGs. If you like any games that fit that mold, I'd highly recommend Age of Wonders 3.

One of the critical mistakes that professional reviewers have piled on this game is that they compared this to Civilization 5. I would really disagree with that approach, and I'd recommend that they compare this to Heroes of Might and Magic and/or King's Bounty the Legend. I feel that Age of Wonders 3 gives FAR more replay value and is incredibly well thought out, especially when compared to the sixth entry of the Heroes series. Diplomacy is second-hand, as the majority of the game is built around the excellent tactical combat. Your goal in this game is to win through total-war and that purity of focus does not get old because of the sheer variety of magic, units and scenarios.

I have played all of the previous Age of Wonders games, and after having been spoiled by this game (and the Golden Realms expansion), I don't think that I can return to them (despite them being incredible games in their own right!).

reviewText:
I whole-heartedly recommend Age of Wonders III to everyone who likes turn-based strategy.

It is a sequel to a game series that manages to hit that sweet spot every sequel wants to hit: To introduce enough new content and mechanics to be its own game, while managing to keep up the feeling of the original.

And it's just as addicting, too. You can play either via network (Internet or local), or the good old hot-seat mode. Just remember to ask your friends to bring a sleeping bag when starting a hotseat game on a huge map, because you might be busy for a week.

There are campaigns of different difficulty for a smooth learning curve, and they also provide you with an interesting story in which your choices matter (Not every choice, of course, but there are points where you can choose which direction the story takes).

The game is a good way to start with TBS games, not only because of the good tutorial provided by the first campaign map, but also the helpful UI. At the beginning of your turn, it shows you everything that happened as messages on the side of the screen, and provides you with a button that tells you which issue to deal with next. That might be considered a bit mothering, but it certainly helps to prevent you from forgetting to order a new building in one of your cities, which can easily slip your mind in an empire of twenty metropolises.

There are a few things that I have issue with, most notably some balance choices, but the devs are active, and listening to the community, so that will only improve over time. As long as there's people willing to buy the game, they will continue to deliver, and not only small balance patches, but also large dlcs with new factions, classes and campaigns.

reviewText: I like 4x. I do. It's a great genre for fans of strategy. After playing hours upon hours of civ 4,  a few of the total war games, warlock 2,  civ 5, then finally beyond earth, I started to get a bit bored on basic science and diplomatic based victories because I just didn't like combat in civ. I picked up Age of Wonders 3 during the past sale, and I'm really enjoying myself. Compared to civ, elements like the way tech and buildings worked took a bit to get used to, but i'm really starting to fall in love with the game. It combines the grand 4x strategy of civ, with a much better combat system similar to what you would see in a hex based strategy game like might and magic, and I feel the fusion was extremely well done. I'm doing something I haven't done in a strategy game like this in a long time, and that is seek out combat. I love the feeling of flanking opponents for massive damage, just to realize I left a commander unguarded and having to wait a few turns before it respawns, and having to build up armies again. I'm still in the middle of my first game, but I can forsee many more in my future, and would recommend this to my civ loving friends out there, especially if you're getting sick of boring combat. 9/10

reviewText:
For all the hex-grid 4X lovers out there, this game is for you.

Think of Civilization 5 with a fantasy theme but add RPG stats and skills to your civ's leader, then they become a controllable hero unit on the map, AND units can stack into armies.
THEN whenever you fight in combat, zoom in to an expanded version of the hex on the map, and its a-whole-nother hex grid to fight over complete with varying terrain, elevation, climate, and occasionally besieging a city or fort's walls!

And then there's the massive depth to each unit. Not just the heroes, but each individual military unit will have their own RPG-style stats with strengths and weaknesses and even crazier promotions than you could possibly imagine (my favorite so far is getting a flying, flame-breathing dragon mount for my leader and handing the horse off to another general)

In the war of 4X, I've seen a lot of games rise to the occasion, and a lot more of them fall flat but this one takes the cake.
